story:
Campaign summary

Handmade by Dafne is a Greek brand of unique handcrafted fashion accessories. Established by myself -Dafne- 6 years ago, with no capital but my own passion for what I do and the support of friends and customers who love my things. It has grown over the years to become our family's sole income source and my products have up to now been sold in shops allover Greece. However, this summer the Greek market has altogether stopped functioning. This is why I need your support to collect the funds that will allow me to participate in an international trade show and put my brand on the global market.

The Handmade by Dafne story

I made my first bag at the age of 5. When I was 10, I borrowed a neighbors sewing machine and saved my weekly allowances to buy a Burda magazine and fabrics and made a dress for my mum and shirt for my dad. That's how I got my first sewing machine! On that same machine I then sewed slings for my babies when I became a mum. I soon had requests from other parents and thus baby slings became my first marketable product and 'Handmade by Dafne' was born. Since then my product range has grown to include bags, backpacks, clutches, purses, earrings, rings pendants, nursing pillows and things for the home as cushions, aprons, bunting and lavender filled hearts.

I screen print my own designs by hand using the most eco friendly inks available – they are Soil Association Certified as Organic Textile Standard and parts of the production are powered by the sun and the wind. Almost all work is done by me – from the design and printing, the actual sewing, packaging and marketing. I have the support of my partner, a skilled graphic designer whose parents once owned a small industry producing athletics apparel.This has given me insights, extensive know how, connections and experiences that have been valuable for the quick development of my business.  

Each product is carefully handcrafted with love in my country studio.

Why I am crowd funding 

 The reason I am using crowdfunding is to keep my business alive. The only viable solution  for me at this point, given the deep rooted crisis in Greece, is to open up to the global market. To do this, I need to participate in an international trade show. The trade show where my products can reach a global clientele is the Premiere Classe trade show in Paris as it supports my style and attracts over 50000 visitors from across the globe. My presence at the fair will cost some 9240 euros in total (exhibition space,  basic transport and accommodation) and that's what I am trying to raise through this campaign. 

I have already  been accepted to the Premiere Classe and was planning to participate. My full Spring-Summer 2016 collection has been designed and produced. However, the current state of the Greek market does not allow me to raise the funds  which is why I am crowdfunding.

The perks - a.k.a. what's in it for you

There is a full list of limited edition products at reduced campaign prices for all of you who contribute. My bestselling Maria backpack and the whole grandmas' product range are only examples. There are also discount coupons to our web shop which you can utilize for your future shopping - until the end of 2015. 
The perks are scheduled to be shipped within October. Customized selections might take a bit longer and ship in November. Please note that there might be variations as to how exactly the pattern on each fabric appears on each product. Shipping costs are provided separately. All products will be shipped by recommended mail ('signed for'). 
Maria backpack perk -our bestselling backpack! Ultra comfortable, stylish and practical



Large grandmas' bag perk

Clutch bag perk

Cross body Clutch perk: This is our new product- not yet to be found in stores so this is your chance to get one of the first of these goodies! Note that there are 2 different perks featuring this bag! One perk at 25 euros which refers to the #1 and #2 version with a jean fabric bottom and strap and another perk at 45 euros which refers to the leather trimmed clutch (versions #3 and #4).

Small Grandmas' Bag Perk

Grandmas' Purse perk

Basic backpack perk

Wallet perk

Versatile Case perk

Small purse and earrings perks


Why this campaign is important

I pride myself in having managed not only to establish but also grow a business  during these harsh times for the Greek economy. I started without any funds 6 years ago (just as the crisis was beginning) and grew my business by investing any profits back into the business - while also supporting my family. 

At this point it is crucial for me to keep my business as it is the means of supporting my family. Apart from the personal level however, I also believe it is crucial to keep Greece producing - not forcing skilled people like myself away. My long term business plan for Handmade by Dafne is to establish a sustainable factory here in the countryside fueled by renewable resources where local people can work under great conditions to offer the world a truly unique high-quality product.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word and send a link to this campaign to anybody else you think might want to contribute - you can use Indiegogo share tools!

Also, keep our web shop www.handmadebydafne.com in mind for the next time you'd like to give someone (yourself included) a unique gift - be it a baby sling, a backpack or a funky purse!

And, if you know a shop that is interested in sourcing unique handcrafted artisan fashion accessories , please give them my contact details.

Thank you all so VERY MUCH for you support!

story:
The iScot story so far...  Since the beginning of 2015  iScot magazine has been at the forefront of carving out a new independent media for Scotland.

In response to demand from a growing section of the population who believe their views are routinely ignored, or even ridiculed, by the mainstream media we vowed to create a new high quality publication free from negativity, bias and condescension.

We promised to deliver a platform to showcase the achievements of Scotland and its people, to identify problems and debate the solutions to create a better, fairer and more inclusive society.

Our aim was to produce a monthly, professional publication which would appeal to a wide domestic and international audience; to demonstrate that as a nation we are far from being “too poor, too wee or too stupid”, as elements of the mainstream media would have us believe. Scotland is a dynamic and forward thinking country with a rich heritage worth celebrating.

We believe we have delivered on that promise!

Some of the comments and reviews on social media about iScot include:

"A fascinating, uplifting and very informative read"

"Thanks for all you're doing for the people of Scotland"

"Excellent - better than The National" (sorry guys :-))

iScot magazine is a pro-Scotland publication. As such it appeals to people who would not otherwise engage with purely political websites. Our mix of content has attracted a wide audience and opened the eyes of many to subjects they would previously have been unaware of.

In the last nine months we have covered a huge range of topics. We have highlighted concerns over fracking, nuclear weapons and political intrigue. We have given a voice to families and campaigners fighting for justice. 

We have promoted Scottish businesses; championed inventiveness; celebrated culture and showcased Scotland to the world. 

All of this has been done alongside spectacular photo spreads, celebrity interviews, aspirational features and regular columns from the likes of Wee Ginger Dug, MajorBloodnok and Will Mcleod’s Letter from America.   Even the First Minister has written for iScot.

Our audience has grown organically every month, mostly as a result of word-of-mouth recommendations and a limited amount of social-media promotion.

We are the only independent grassroots pro-Scotland publication available in newsagents. But, if we are to compete against the stranglehold of the mainstream media we need to reach more people and increase our editorial coverage.

It is time to expand and we would like your help to do it!
iScot is looking to raise funds to help improve our services and reach a wider audience. We have two main funding requirements
(1) We will use the money raised to invest in more quality content. There are numerous worthy topics and subjects all too often ignored by the MSM which rail against the established view which deserve to be covered, investigated and published. 
To do this properly we need to recruit the services of more journalists, photographers, video makers, broadcasters and professional experts. The majority of our funding will be allocated to these activities.

(2) We need to launch a national advertising campaign to make more people aware of the magazine, and its positive view of Scotland and its people.  Many people don't have access to social media and rely instead on traditional MSM print and broadcast sources for information.  iScot needs to advertise its presence to that audience to offer an alternate view.

If we reach our funding target, we aim to increase the profile of iScot by producing the first ever crowd funded TV advert for an independent pro Scotland publication.  This will be done in advance of the 2016 elections.  

Please join our journey and support our grassroots media revolution.

story:
Our project turns a blighted alley into a vital community gathering space, with a stage, rain garden, labyrinth and mosaic game boards.

Our project is named Maple Valley Pocket Park 2.0 because this is our second campaign to fund our project through crowd-funding.  If at first you don't succeed, try, try, again!  Our first experience with crowd-funding was with another crowd-funding website.  Even though, we had over $27,000 pledged to our project, we were unable to collect due to the all or nothing requirement.  Since that campaign, we have kept our resolve to install our Pocket Park and have raised additional funds in donations and grants.  Now, we are using Indiegogo to help us raise the last $23,000 for the Pocket Park installation.  (If we are fortunate enough to raise more funds than that, we have designs to install laser-cut metal banners with a 4-seasons theme on the wall.)

We are about to take an alley in a wasted space between a grocery store and a coffee shop, full of shopping carts and dumpsters, and transform it into an innovative Pocket Park that will provide recreation, gathering space, and arts access for residents of Maple Valley WA. With about $35,000 already pledged from grants, donations and local businesses, we are crowd-funding the remaining $23,000 necessary to complete the project for two reasons: First, the Pocket Park project is for and about community, and we want to give our community the chance to get behind it. Second--we are ready to pour concrete, and it's time  to come up with the rest of the cash!

The space is a long, narrow alley which residents tend to walk past without noticing its existence--it looks unloved and little-tended. But that's all over now! Working in collaboration with the all-volunteer, non-profit Maple Valley Creative Arts Council, artist Kathleen Fruge-Brown has designed a complete makeover of the space. The Park's design addresses the following specific needs: 


A Space for Reflection and Recreation

The Pocket Park is a gem for those needing a quiet moment in a stressful day. The design of the Park is based on three roundels connected by a serpentine path. At the entrance, the first roundel is a large circular graphic, the 'Ripple', in hand-painted stained-concrete. Leading onward past a circular rain garden, the path incorporates a children's hopscotch court to inspire some old-school play. The path then leads to a labyrinth, created in the pavement with glass mosaic. Our labyrinth is based on an ancient seed design; a meditative walk along its spiraling path brings you to a circular bench at its heart.

Pocket Park design, based on three roundels

A Space for Gathering and Community

The seven curved benches and dozen or so boulders do more than provide seating--they are designed and located to encourage conversation and to allow small groups to use the Pocket Park for meeting. The boulders will be engraved with words of welcome, in English and in other tongues currently spoken as first languages by children in Maple Valley's Tahoma School District. The 'Ripple" graphic invites meditation on the theme of the individual's effect on the community: The three benches located near the center of the 'Ripple' will each bear one section of the motto "From each small act...the ripples spread...ever outward".

"Ripple" graphic with the slogan that will be cast into the curved benches; labyrinth plan

A Space for the Arts

The small stage at the far end of the Park is designed for lunchtime or summer evening concerts, poetry readings, etc. Maple Valley has a thriving music community, with local performances already occurring at the Maple Valley Creative Arts Center and other community locales. This new venue will give more opportunities to local performers and will increase their audience by luring in shoppers who will stop to listen. A public artwork in its own right, the Park will also include brightly-colored children's mosaics in the hopscotch court and in game boards built into the benches.

Stage for concerts and performances

story:
Short Summary

My name is Flavia Ursa, I am 23 years old and I was born in Romania. I completed my undergraduate degree at the University of St Andrews in Scotland, where I studied Psychology. During the four years spent there, I discovered the important part that research plays in the field in order to improve our understanding of the human mind and to find ways of treating mental disorders. I have done numerous internships in children's and adult's psychiatric hospitals in Romania, as well a summer in Ghana in a Psychiatric Hospital. I worked as a research assistant in the Psychology department at my University, where I learned the practical side of research.

Throughout my studies and extracurricular activities I have found that my passion lies in clinical and forensic research, and applied for a Master's program in research at Lund University, Sweden. I have been here for a bit over one semester, and my studies have gone very well. I am very happy with the academic training I am receiving, and I feel the program provides the stepping stones I need in reaching my goal of becoming a researcher. I have received top grades for my Statistics and Methodology class, and already started planning my Master's thesis that will be conducted in a clinical setting with one of the top researchers in the department as my supervisors.

The only negative side of studying in Sweden is the fact that it is a very expensive country. Even though I don't have to pay tuition fees, being from a European Union country, the living costs are very high. My home country, Romania, unfortunately does not provide any kind of financial support to its students, and I don't qualify for any Swedish scholarships or grants. During my undergraduate studies in the United Kingdom I have had part-time jobs in bars and restaurants in order to support myself, but here it has been impossible to get one due to the fact I don't know Swedish. My family is unable to support me owing to the large difference in income and spending between Romania and Sweden.

Thus, my aim is to try to identify ways of funding my living costs for the remaining four months of the first year of Master's studies. I am very passionate and driven, and I refuse to believe money issues can hamper my education. Through your help, I can continue focusing on my studies, getting highly skilled in research, and acquiring the theoretical and practical knowledge that will ensure I get the job I've been working towards. 

What I Need & What You Get

I have four months left of this academic year. The Swedish government informs students the minimum amount of money they need is SEK 7,800 (approx. EUR 850) per month. This is corroborated by my experience of living here these previous months. This is what a breakdown of my monthly budget looks like:

Rent

SEK 3,700

Food

SEK 1,800

Pre-paid card/ phone

SEK 200

Books

SEK 500

Printing Credit

SEK 200

Transportation

SEK 200

Miscellaneous

SEK 900

Total

SEK 7,500 = EUR 820 / month

Thus, I have decided to set a goal of EUR 3,500, that also covers Indiegogo fees.

With your help, I can get by in the next four months. In return, I shall update my blog about my life is Sweden weekly. Through it, I'm hoping to provide some first-hand insight on being an international student in Sweden to prospective students, as well as information on the course I'm taking, and psychology in general. For higher contributors, I will write short review papers on a psychology topic of your choice or send essays on specific interesting topics I've researched and written about. The information will be corroborated scientifically and obtained solely from trustworthy research journals. Even if I don't reach my goal, covering any small part of my living costs will be of great help.

The Impact

Psychology is a relatively new discipline, and a lot of research is still needed in the field. Mental illness is only now beginning to be recognized and accepted in the Western world, and many awareness campaigns have improved the public knowledge on the subject. But there is so much still to be learned about the brain, and about the best ways of treating mental illness that affect so many people worldwide. I consider that I can make a difference. My main area of interest is the effect of childhood abuse on mental well-being, and antisocial personality disorder.  I have already written review papers on the subject, and know the imperative need to stop such abuses, but also how vital it is to find ways of helping such children recover and develop in a healthy manner, and not perpetuate the circle of abuse.

I consider education is the most empowering tool that exists, and everybody should have access to education without having to worry about not being able to pay the rent, buy books, or food. While at the moment I am the one in need of help, this experience has opened my eyes to such issues, and I have promised myself to help others in my situation in the future.

Risks & Challenges

Studying abroad is a real challenge. Studying abroad with no financial stability is a lot more taxing on one's mental health and optimism. Even so, I have found I am strong enough to take each challenge one step at a time, and strive to find solutions. I do not give up. I realise that even if I reach my goal, my second year will still not be covered. I plan on working full-time this summer to be able to cover at least some of the costs for the next academic year. My Swedish will also improve considerably until then, since I am studying by myself and will also take a Swedish language course provided by the University. Thus, my prospects for finding a part-time job will also improve, especially since I have solid experience in the hospitality business from my time in St Andrews. Therefore, I consider that although there are some challenges I will most definitely have to face, I have proved to myself on numerous occasions I will be able to surpass them.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand not everyone has the financial means to contribute through donations. You would be doing me a great favour just by sharing my campaign. Thank you very much!

driven, and I refuse to believe money issues can hamper my education. Through
your help, I can continue focusing on my studies, getting highly skilled in
research, and acquiring the theoretical and practical knowledge that will
ensure I get the job I've been working towards. 
What I Need & What You Get
I have
four months left of this academic year. The Swedish government informs students
the minimum amount of money they need is SEK 7,800 (approx. EUR 850) per month.
This is corroborated by my experience of living here these previous months. This
is what a breakdown of my monthly budget looks like:




Rent


SEK
  3,700 




Food


SEK
  1,800 




Pre-paid
  card/ phone


SEK 200
  




Books


SEK 500
  




Printing
  Credit


SEK 200
  




Transportation


SEK 200
  




Miscellaneous
  


SEK 900
  








Total


SEK
  7,500 = EUR 820 / month




Thus, I have decided to set a
goal of EUR 3,500, that also covers Indiegogo fees.

With your help, I can get by in the next four months. In return, I shall
update my blog about my life is Sweden weekly. Through it, I'm hoping to
provide some first-hand insight on being an international student in Sweden to
prospective students, as well as information on the course I'm taking, and
psychology in general. For higher contributors, I will write short review
papers on a psychology topic of your choice or send essays on specific
interesting topics I've researched and written about. The information will be
corroborated scientifically and obtained solely from trustworthy research
journals. Even if I don't reach my goal, covering any small part of my living
costs will be of great help.
The Impact
Psychology
is a relatively new discipline, and a lot of research is still needed in the
field. Mental illness is only now beginning to be recognized and accepted in
the Western world, and many awareness campaigns have improved the public
knowledge on the subject. But there is so much still to be learned about the
brain, and about the best ways of treating mental illness that affect so many
people worldwide. I consider that I can make a difference. My main area of
interest is the effect of childhood abuse on mental well-being, and antisocial
personality disorder.  I have already written review papers on the
subject, and know the imperative need to stop such abuses, but also how vital
it is to find ways of helping such children recover and develop in a healthy
manner, and not perpetuate the circle of abuse.
I
consider education is the most empowering tool that exists, and everybody
should have access to education without having to worry about not being able to
pay the rent, buy books, or food. While at the moment I am the one in need of
help, this experience has opened my eyes to such issues, and I have promised
myself to help others in my situation in the future.
Risks & Challenges
Studying
abroad is a real challenge. Studying abroad with no financial stability is a
lot more taxing on one's mental health and optimism. Even so, I have found I am
strong enough to take each challenge one step at a time, and strive to find
solutions. I do not give up. I realise that even if I reach my goal, my second
year will still not be covered. I plan on working full-time this summer to be
able to cover at least some of the costs for the next academic year. My Swedish
will also improve considerably until then, since I am studying by myself and
will also take a Swedish language course provided by the University. Thus, my
prospects for finding a part-time job will also improve, especially since I
have solid experience in the hospitality business from my time in St Andrews.
Therefore, I consider that although there are some challenges I will most
definitely have to face, I have proved to myself on numerous occasions I will
be able to surpass them.
Other Ways You Can Help
I
understand not everyone has the financial means to contribute through
donations. You would be doing me a great favour just by sharing my campaign.
Thank you very much!

story:
Hi there! I’m Gandalf (Nichelle).

I need to get out of this desert full of dumb roadrunners getting caught in my tires. I rather swim with dolphins and walk around barefoot like a real Hobbit studying Lord of The Rings in New Zealand!

So my story is this: I totally can’t receive enough loans, scholarships, and grants to cover this study abroad experience through Arizona State University for this July summer semester. I’m over here eating Ramen noodles and spaghetti all the time. However, I do love me some spaghetti! I’ve been collecting printer cartridges, cans, and plastic bottles too. Like how much more broke can I seem? Okay, I’m not entirely broke, just semi-broke. Like I can splurge on some Chinese food and BBQ here and there after going through some rough nights studying @ the ASU library while listening to Britney Spears. 

So I totally need to figure out how to pay off my tuition approximately by the beginning of May at the latest. I mean, the earlier the better. What’s the cost? I need a grand total of $6,545 for tuition alone. Yikes, I know! The passport is about $200 and maybe some change (cause they like to charge extra money for “handling” it). The plane ticket? Oh golly, that’s like $1,900 separately. Yeah, I know that’s basically a mortgage payment. And then extra spending money to eat because they actually don’t feed you every meal on this trip. I’m only basically fundraising the tuition portion since I applied for over 20 scholarships and grants thus far. Might have to sell a kidney while I'm at it.

Impossible to get these things? Nope. Inconvenient to get them in short times notice? Totally.

I don’t know how this fundraising crowdfunding stuff really even works. I feel like it’s simpler than what I make it to be in my mind. I’m old school and don’t really like using technological things. But I’ll be darned if I have to travel in someone’s suitcase illegally to New Zealand if I can’t reach this goal.

So here’s what I’m proposing: help a college girl out to become more cultural diverse and educated overseas. I’ll definitely make it worth your while. I’ve created a beautifully non-complex system to do/send you things in return for your donation. It makes my experience come to life inside of you, while I’m the one actually exploring New Zealand.

If you don’t feel like donating, then it’s honestly okay. I don’t want people feeling too obligated to donate. I would be excited enough if you read this far. Thank you for putting up with my shenanigans. I hope I’ve won your heart…and consumed your soul.

P.S. Yes, that is definitely me in a Gandalf costume. Why would I photoshop that when you can look at the real deal?

P.P.S. Yes, I will be wearing this costume all around New Zealand while exploring Hobbiton and climbing a volcano.

story:
Amal is a registered, non-profit, community-based organization focused on addressing the needs of women and their families affected by domestic abuse. 

Today we are reaching out to you for an URGENT APPEAL - donations have steadily been decreasing; however, the work Amal does has been steadily increasing, and we no longer have the finances to continue to provide the services that are so essential to the women we meet with every day. We need any and all the donations that we can get, or risk having to shut our doors in THE MONTH OF JUNE.

OUR MISSION
TO PROVIDE SUPPORT AND ASSISTANCE IN A CULTURALLY COMPETENT MANNER TO WOMEN AFFECTED BY DOMESTIC ABUSE IN HOPES OF FOSTERING THEIR WELLBEING AND DEVELOPMENT.

The Amal Centre for Women is an open, inclusive, and welcoming centre that collaborates with women to improve their living conditions, develop their independence, and heal the wounds caused by their experience with domestic abuse. The Centre offers psychosocial services that respond to the needs of the women, while also conducting community outreach to raise awareness of domestic abuse in ethnocultural communities. 

At Amal, we are committed to:

  • Promoting the well-being of women and children in a holistic manner, at both the individual and family level
  • Serving as an individually-tailored referral center that links the members of various communities to appropriate and relevant services
  • Developing effective communication skills within couples to encourage healthy familial environments
  • Building bridges with other community groups and organizations that promote similar objectives
  • Raising awareness through education in multicultural communities of the rights and responsibilities of women

So What can YOU do?

For many years now, The Amal Center for Women has been lending a helping hand to a community in need - but right now, we need you.

Donations have steadily been decreasing; however, the work Amal does has been steadily increasing, and we no longer have the finances to continue to provide the services that are so essential to the women we meet with every day. We strive to provide quality service that will really influence a change in the lives of the women that trust us with their deepest and most concerning situations.

Consider this our turn to call on you to help us with a concerning situation. We need any and all the donations that we can get, or risk having to shut our doors in THE MONTH OF JUNE.

Our goal is to raise at least $25,000 through this indiegogo campaign. To view Amal’s 2014 Financial Statements, 2014 Annual Report, and facts about Amal’s services and costs, visit our website at www.amalwomencenter.ca.

Please take a moment to help us in our plight to continue keeping our doors open and being a staple within the community.

story:
About Us

TERRA DACICA AETERNA is the first association in Romania which addresses the reenactment related with the ancient period. Historical reenactment is a way through which the history is literally “re-lived” by manufacturing clothing, weapons, tools, households, which the reenactment enthusiasts (re-enactors) use during some moments more or less directed. Manufacturing the equipment is done by studying historical sources relating to the period of time that needs to be “revived” so that everything is as close to the reality of those times as it can be.


The historical period chosen by us to be presented to the public is the one in which military conflicts took place between the Dacians, Romans and Sarmatians, which approximately accounts for the period between the 1st century BC to the 2nd century AD. As a result, three main groups are present within the association: the Dacians, the Romans and the Sarmatians. Aside from these groups, the equipment of some of the allies of these peoples have been recreated within the association, such as the the Celts, the Burs, the Palmyrens, the Batavians. Moments are re-enacted from the military history of these peoples as well as from the civil or religious life.

Currently, Terra Dacica Aeterna has about 70 members from all over the country. The official seat of the association is in Cluj Napoca, and one subsidiary have been established in Deva and another one will follow this year in Sibiu.


We have many invites to several historical events across Romania and the countries around (Bulgaria, Poland, Hungary, France). We are "travelling in time", re-living the history and entertaining the others with our presence, our workshops and battle demonstrations.

Our biggest  problem is that we do not have our own transport vehicle. We are forced to rent a bus everytime we need to go to a festival and that costs a lot of money. 

We are mostly using the money we receive for our representations in renewing our equipments, making new costumes, weapons, armours, etc. We are trying to avoid as much as possible in the future renting buses anymore because that produces a big hole in our budget.

We have decided to start this campaign with hopes and dreams of having our own bus. For that, we need your help and we let you decide if we are worthy or not of it.

Your help counts the most for us because without it we won't be able to achieve this goal, to reach this dream we have.

What We Need & What You Get

As you already have seen above, we need a bus. We cannot afford to buy a new bus but, we are trying, with your help to raise 25000 $ that will allow us to buy a second hand bus.

With some luck we would be able to buy a trailer for the bus as well, because we have a lot of equipment to transport (our camp is big).

To show you our gratitude for helping us in this quest we offer you unique perks. We think they are unique because being reenactors and "traveling in time" we are doing a lot of experimental Archeology projects during our workshops: Pottery, Jewellery, Swordsmithing, Armoursmithing, Weaving, Metalworking, etc. We are thinking to offer you some of our hand manufactured products, as tokens of gratitude for some of the perks. 

Now, if we do not reach our goal, the money raised during the campaign will still help us paying our rent at our workshop (base), buying more raw materials for producing all listed above and, because we won't have any other option... rent again buses for travelling to events we're invited. We really hope that won't be the case anymore. 

The Impact

Terra Dacica Aeterna aims at presenting ancient history on the present-territory of Romania. Our methods are unconventional, different from those employed in schools. We believe that history, the way it is taught in schools, is an incompletely adequate way of learning about the past. Thus, our association’s goal is to bring the general public closer to ancient history through experimental archaeology and reenactment. With the aid of experimental archaeology, the members of the association have recreated ancient equipment, tools, and buildings by using, as much as possible, the working methods and tools available during that period.

Through reenactment (an English word lacking an exact equivalent in Romania, the closest term being a synonym of “re-creation”), those objects are used, trying to discover as much data as possible on their functionality. Thus, both us and the public present at our shows, discover pieces of the puzzle that is the ancient history of the Dacians, Romans, and Sarmatians, in a way that stimulates the curiosity and desire to discovery that lies in each of us. 

History learnt from school can be thus completed through lived history. The experience we gained over these years has taught us that many of those present at our events became really interested in ancient history, an interest that history taught in school did not succeed in stirring.

Besides all these, just think about the children that come to events we are invited as well, able to see real-like battles in front of their eyes. They are totally mesmerized by our battles and most of the time, after the battle demonstration ends, we are besieged by them. We are offering them our weapons to feel in their tiny hands and our helmets to try on. 

There is no bigger joy than to see a child irradiating with happiness and amazement when he is geared with some of our battle equipment and weapons.

This is the difference your help will make. You help us to be able to reach more events and bring happiness in the hearts of more and more children and adults alike.

This is the first project of this kind we are doing and we really hope that your help will make a difference. A good one.

Spread the word, think with your heart and give culture and education a chance. History is not a "science" digested by everyone but we make it more accessible, beautiful and spectacular.  People have the chance to see how the life was 2000 years ago, how the battles were handled, how the things were made, the tools used in the making process. An old, ancient world for us to love and study but a new one for most of the people that see us. 

Help us share this love!

Make it possible for us to have our own bus. Would be much, much easier to go to more events and save money for our equipments, supplies and our workshop rent.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word. Share this campaign with your friends. There are a lot of powerful sharing tools here on Indiegogo. Use them. Any help you provide is much appreciated!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

We are Recycled Life!

What we do:

  • Aid families who are faced with a financial hardship caused by, sudden, and severe medical illness of a family member.
  • All of our donated clothing, housewares, electronics, and furniture, are given back to people in the community who need them.
  • Work with at risk teens coming out of the juvenile system to provide jobs, training, mentoring, spiritual healing, guidance, and an opportunity to grow. 
  • Income tax and accounting services, financial counseling on better ways to budget and manage money.
  • Credit Enhancement services, and education on the credit system, how it works, why its important, and how to use it responsibly. 
  • Insurance services and consultation for families to help fill any gaps or liability they may have.
  • Job coaching and entrepreneurial mentoring.
  • Real estate and rental services, including education for families who need help with selling, buying, or renting a home, apartment or condominium.
  • Résumé assistance
  • Job placement assistance

What We Need & What You Get

We are launching a program for the kids called "Arts & Parts" 

This program will be a mentored program to teach kids how things work and how to build things.  Kids will have an opportunity to take apart and build computers, and other household electronics.

We will also work with the kids to build things from wood, scrapbooking, and make clothing from fabric and patterns, and much much more.

The Impact

The program is designed to keep the kids engaged in activities that stimulate the mind, and allow them to see how things they use in everyday life are made and how they work.  It will allow them to be creative without having to worry about breaking something at home. 

Risks & Challenges

The challenges we face are in the communities that we serve.  Kids end up sitting idle and without activities like these, they end up finding things to do that sometimes lead them down the wrong path.  We want to encourage their creativity and hopefully keep them off the streets.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to help financially, please spread the word on Facebook, or with anyone you may know.  

Thank you in advance for all your support!

story:
Short Summary

Last-Resort is an apparel & accessories company.  But what makes us who we are is not simply a love for luxury but a respect for the journey.  We’ve been to every down-trodden metropolis; every forgotten suburb—but we’re headed to a place of limitless possibilities.  


Our high-quality products are created for lovers of art—for people who collect passport stamps like loose change.  We represent people who love living life and who won’t compromise their vision just to be accepted. 

Made in America, with care for the Future.
Our products are produced in the USA. We create masterful pieces with the assistance of Ruben Spitz and the great staff at Headwear Creations Inc. They make the very best high quality American made headwear.  

In addition to producing accessories Last Resort has initiated a 12 week course teaching youth from Newark, NJ how to live out their passions now, instead of waiting until they “grow up.”  Truth be told, many of our inner-city youth have faced more troubles than your average adult.  We understand this completely, given that we’ve had to navigate the same inner-city gauntlet. 

What we’re looking to create long-term is an on-going course for youth aged 15-17 that encompasses real-world entrepreneurial skills with a focus on the fashion industry.  More importantly, we’re going to give our students what we never had; practical business knowledge and a team of mentors who care about seeing them live their dreams.

Our focus is to produce the hats designed in collaboration with the students whom participated in our 12-week entrepreneurial course and also to create a way for those students to directly benefit from the sales of the product. Last Resort will also be presenting the hats designed in collaboration with our students at Capsule Trade Show in addition to our latest complete collection.

Proceeds from the sales of the hats produced in collaboration with the students of our fashion entrepreneurs course will be used to create grants for the students involved that can be used towards funding their very own start up ideas or used directly in support of their pursuit of higher education.

With your help, we can change the lives of young adults who might otherwise be swallowed up by a system that doesn’t appreciate their uniqueness.  We want our Last Resort to be their best option.


What We Need & What You Get

We need your help in reaching our goal of $10,000 to bring our vision to reality. All funding will go towards covering the production, materials and launch of our collaborative collection with the students of our Fashion Entrepreneurs course. It will also be put towards the attendance of Capsule tradeshow where we will be presenting our latest complete collection alongside the hats from the collaboration.



The Hats:
The Bora Cap

- Red Cotton Twill Body, Black Leather Trim &  Hand Weaved Black Leather Braid. 

The Cayman Hat

-  Black Denim Body, Leather Trim Brim & Contrast Olive Denim on Bottom of Brim.


Press:


The Impact

This project is the cumulative result of months of design thinking, hand-sewn prototyping, drafting and redrafting of patterns, surveying, and countless conversations to improve our products and amplify our mission. More than anything, we want to see this project through and empower you with the ability to be a model for the support of youth empowerment and fashion. We promise to do whatever it takes to make that possible!

We believe integrity is the heart and soul of every successful company. Our integrity is defined by how we handle the risks and challenges we face. We will do everything it takes to make sure our customers are happy, not only with the products they receive, but with our service as well.

Risks & Challenges

We've spent most of the last year working with our team and partners to mitigate as many risks as possible, however, we know there will still be hurdles along the way. We will always be transparent with our community about challenges, including these:

IN THE EVENT OF EPIC DEMAND

We have laid out contingency plans in the event of massive support from backers. We’ve confirmed that our manufacturing partners can take on additional units.

SUPPLIERS

While we do not foresee material supply to be a problem, we do acknowledge the unique set of challenges that arise when collecting raw material from multiple sources rather than ordering yardage from a factory. The most prominent challenge is the potential for delays, but we will try to mitigate this by making sure there is advance notice given to suppliers on the volume we expect from our campaign.

SHIPMENT

We're shipping our products through the mail. There is general risk in the reliability of shipping companies, but we'll make sure we keep track of your order at all times and communicate its progress openly to you.


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

We are asking you to share this project on your social media platforms throughout the campaign and let people know about our project.  

  • Tag us @lastresortintl and use our hashtag #createparadise when you share our project as we'll be on the lookout! 
  • Additionally, you can copy the link  of this page to share via email & on any other forums or platform you may use!

Your support means the world to us!
story_txt:
Short SummaryLast-Resort is an apparel & accessories company.  But what makes us who we are is not simply a love for luxury but a respect for the journey.  We’ve been to every down-trodden metropolis; every forgotten suburb—but we’re headed to a place of limitless possibilities.  
Our high-quality products are created for lovers of art—for people who collect passport stamps like loose change.  We represent people who love living life and who won’t compromise their vision just to be accepted. Made in America, with care for the Future.Our products are produced in the USA. We create masterful pieces with the assistance of Ruben Spitz and the great staff at Headwear Creations Inc. They make the very best high quality American made headwear.

story:
Brief Summary

The Youth Media programs are a Scholarship and Applied Skills plan for teen’s ages 13-18. We are a Non-Profit Organization hoping to provide these programs at no cost to the teens or their family.                               
    
Our program is focused on teaching new and relevant skills through "hands on" classes, and instilling better values helping them progress through opportunities to build a better future for themselves. Statistically, Youth media programs have proven to be a great avenue for many young people throughout stages of their life. Not only has it helped to decrease dropout rates in high school and bring the graduation percentage up; It has also encouraged higher education and entrepreneurial opportunities.   

We want to cover Multimedia Art in Photo & Video Production, as well as Graphic Design, Internet Radio & Broadcasting, Creative Writing, Mentor-ship, Leadership, Project Management, and many more relevant skill-sets as we develop. Our programs will grow and change over the years.

What We Need

We need funding to cover many of the start-up and operation expenses until grant funding is in place. 
The funds will be used for:

  • Computers for Graphic Design, Video Editing, and Researching 
  • Staff Salary
  • Instructors for Graphic Design, Creative Writing, Video Production, Photography, Internet Radio Broadcasting and other classes.
  • Equipment to allow youth who cant afford any personal things to still be able to fully participate
  • Maintaining & Upgrading the Facility
  • Professional Kitchen to accommodate the Culinary aspects of our programs     
For more information, please visit our site linked below.
www.localpassbookyouthmedia.com

story:
How was it like growing up in socialist Cuba? The award-winning exhibition project Pioneros: Building Cuba's Socialist Childhood provides some answers, showcasing the material world of childhood through the decades of the 1960s, 1970s, and 1980s on the Soviet-influenced country.

We need your help to successfully inaugurate this exhibition in the Arnold and Sheila Aronson Galleries of Parsons, The New School for Design, on September 14 through October 2, 2015, and pay for the costs of website and catalogue design and production. 

Pioneros: Building Cuba's Socialist Childhood is a project of Cuba Material, a web platform dedicated to archiving and sharing information on Cuban material culture, partially funded by a grant from New Challenge, a fund for student social innovation at The New School; and the Sheila Johnson Design Center at Parsons, The New School for Design.

With your help, we will be able to present well-documented background on how life under Cuba’s communism actually was, from the point of view of a child.

Contributions are tax exempted. All contributors will be listed in the exhibition website and catalogue, and those contributing with more than $100.00 will also receive perks, most of them limited-edition photographs by artist Geandy Pavon. 

If we don't reach our goals, only a pdf catalogue will be produced, which will be available at the website for downloading.

If you cannot contribute with money, you can still help us spread the word!

story:
•  Maine energy-smart kids can and do influence changes that help our environment.

The Maine Energy Education Program (MEEP) needs your help now, to continue working with school aged children at their home, school or community venue.  Funding levels have reached a critical low while we're (1) waiting for grant funding support and (2) transitioning to fee based programming.  We need your help during this transition.

With your help we'll be able to continue to offer our Electricity & and Environment Classroom Workshops to schools that request them while we’re transitioning to fee based programming.

These are community-based renewable energy lessons from which kids learn how alternative energy is made and used and how it impacts our lives.  They get charged up to take action to help "green" their schools and homes by better managing energy choices.  Every family that makes smarter energy choices helps reduce the impacts of pollution on the environment.

MEEP reached over 75,000 kids in the past 8 years and over 4,500 so far this year.  We have a proven track record of success.

Why do we need your support now?

* We have been highly successful for many years, but funding for education has dropped dramatically in Maine, from both state and corporate grants for small non-profit curriculum-based projects like ours.

* Until now, we've been offering programming in schools at no charge, but the decline in resources is forcing us to move to charging a fee for materials and staff time.

* Our Plan is to immediately establish a fund to help schools transition through that change by initially offsetting some of the new fee for schools that can't afford the full cost. Any grants we receive will help us sustain that fund through the transition period.

Here's how your donations will be used to implement the changes and sustain the program: You can help us reach over 2,000 kids this fall by contributing to our transition fund. Donations will be used to help needy schools offset a portion of the costs of sponsoring MEEP’s community-based renewable energy lessons. 

Become a MEEP Champion: help us continue to create an energy-smart citizenry in 2015!  Please consider a donation for: 

  $20 sponsor one child attending a workshop

  $35 buy classroom supplies

  $50 assist with classroom handouts expenses

  $100 KILOWATT sponsor one 1st-3rd grade class for a session of My Light

  $250 MEGAWATT sponsor one 4th+ grade class (12+ students) for a session of Electricity & the Environment

  $500+ GIGAWATT sponsor – multiple classroom presentations

To thank you for your support of our program, we’ll post your name or your organization logo as sponsors on our website.  Check out our website  (meepnews.org) to see thetypes of exciting activities we've offered in Maine classrooms for 20+ years.

What We Need & What You Get

•    By becoming a MEEP Champion: Your support will go directly to classroom programming, connecting kids to resources and ideas that will change the way we and they use energy and reduce the impacts of climate change.

•    With YOUR HELP we will keep the programming going during the transition. Our low overhead expenses ensure that your support will go directly into experiences for school aged children at their home, school or community venue.

WHY?  Maine kids andtheir families benefit from learning about energy choices that help reduce impacts of air pollution and climate change.

•    Kids value being able to make life better and help others succeed.  With small amounts of funding we can achieve great things together.

•    There's a good chance that you know a child who has experienced first-hand the benefits of a MEEP visit to their school.  MEEP reached over 75,000 kids in the past 8 years and over 4,500 so far this year.  We have a proven track record of success.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

·  Please help us get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.

·  Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
¡La escuela para niños con necesidades educativas especiales ha estado al servicio de la comunidad durante 20 años, y hoy necesita nuestro apoyo! 

                                     (To read in English please see below)

School of Joy es una escuela para niños con discapacidad física e intelectual, ubicada en Belén, Palestina. Fundada por la Sra. Randa Abu Saada quién donó una casa para el establecimiento y estableció la escuela inicialmente con 5 profesores y que hoy cuenta con 11 profesores permanentes y estudiantes voluntarios de las universidades locales que apoyan el trabajo. 

¿Por qué necesitamos tu ayuda?

School of Joy funciona en la casa de tres pisos donde se instaló originalmente hace 20 años. En estos momentos aspiramos a renovar su infraestructura con el fin de recibir más estudiantes y ofrecer espacios adecuados para los estudiantes con discapacidades físicas e intelectuales. 

La escuela tiene tres salas en desuso en el primer piso. Salas que si son reparadas pueden evitarle a los niños el doloroso proceso de subir uno o dos pisos por las escaleras para asistir a clases. Los espacios existen pero requieren arduo trabajo para que puedan ser nuevamente utilizados.

Los resultados del proyecto 

  • Acceso directo de los niños a las salas de clasesdesde la entrada del colegio, sin tener que subir las escaleras diariamente.  
  • Aumentar el número de estudiantes de la escuela, disminuyendo su lista de espera. 
  • Comenzar un programa pre-escolar para niños más pequeños, una sentida demanda de las familias. 

Conoce a Ibrahim


    


¿Qué hace importante a esta escuela?

 El corazón de este proyecto escolar es ofrecer educación y un ambiente seguro para niños en situación de discapacidad física e intelectual en un contexto donde prima la falta de acceso y mucho desconocimiento de parte de la población en torno a la discapacidad. Estas dificultades se suman a otras limitaciones que sufren los niños palestinos producto de la ocupación militar, tales como restricciones en desplazamiento a centros de salud y falta de oportunidades laborales para sus padres.   School of Joy es un foco que permite entregar herramientas a los niños y orientar a sus familias para lograr mayor inclusión. 

Conoce a Firas


La escuela actualmente acoge a 50 estudiantes entre las edades de 6 y 18 años. Los estudiantes además de  educación formal reciben orientación vocacional y se les enseñan técnicas de tallado en madera de olivo, uno de los oficios más importantes en Belén, esto con el fin de facilitarles el ingreso al mundo laboral y por ende alcanzar mayores niveles de autonomía. Estos niños y sus familias hacen enormes esfuerzos para asistir al colegio, ya que provienen de diferentes localidades de la provincia de Belén y otros pueblos cercanos en Palestina. La mayoría de las familias carecen de recursos económicos y muchas veces no cuentan con conocimientos suficiente para apoyar la integración de sus hijos como miembros activos de la sociedad. 

¡Tú puedes apoyar este proyecto inclusivo!

¿Quiénes somos?

La Fundación Belén 2000 es una organización sin fines de lucro radicada en Chile que busca mejorar la calidad de vida de los niños en Palestina, a través de ayuda solidaria. Los fondos obtenidos nos permiten contribuir en forma permanente en tres ejes: educación, salud y recreación. Hasta la fecha hemos entregado más de 4.800 becas, enviado 12 misiones médicas de diversas especialidades médicas hemos aportado a la construcción de 9 parques recreacionales con ayuda de la Fundación. 

A través de nuestra presencia y el trabajo que realizamos en Palestina hemos podido evidenciar las necesidades de la escuela! Si bien ellos reciben donaciones a nivel local y algunos ingresos propios, estos no son suficientes y deben recurrir permanentemente a benefactores y organizaciones internacionales para desarrollar su proyecto escolar. La fundación quiere contribuir a su desarrollo permanente a través de esta campaña y con un equipo de trabajo tanto en Chile como en Palestina, que apoyará  la ejecución en terreno del proyecto.



Cuando alcancemos la meta propuesta (gracias a tu ayuda!!!) la campaña continuará abierta para quienes quieran seguir donando. Todo el dinero extra recaudado será destinado para restaurar el patio del colegio para que los niños puedan jugar en un espacio seguro, considerando la escasez de espacios seguros al aire libre en Palestina. 

Otras formas de ayudar

Si no puedes hacer una contribución monetaria existen otras formas de colaborar, ¡ayúdanos a difundir esta campaña!, compártenos en Facebook, twitea sobre nosotros, escribe un correo a tus familiares y amigos. Puedes usar las herramientas disponibles de Indiegogo.  Gracias! 

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This school for children with disabilities has been serving its   community for the past twenty years, and is now in need of our support!

School of Joy is a small town school in the Bethlehem area that offers education and a safe environment for poor children with physical and intellectual disabilities. Founded by Mrs. Randa Abu Saada, who donated a house and recruited a staff of five teachers. Now it has eleven teachers and several 

Why do we need your help?

School  of Joy still remains in the three level house originally donated over 20 years ago. It aspires to restore the infrastructure to be able to receive more children, and offer adequate facilities for their current physically and mentally challenged students. 

The school has three abandoned rooms on the ground floor. Rooms that can save the children from the pain to climb one or two floors  using stairs to go to class. The rooms already exist, but are in need a extensive of work to make them active and useful facilities.  

The results of the project 

  • Allow  first floor access to a facility directly connected to the entrance and            the outside yard. Without having to climb stairs daily.
  • Increase the capacity to receive more children to the school hence decreasing the number of students on the waiting list.
  • Start a small kindergarten for children with special needs. The school already received many requests from families but unfortunately does not have the capacity to admit them.



Why is this school important?

 The heart of School of Joy is to provide children a space where integration and acceptance is possible taking into consideration that still there is lack of awareness about their needs and abilities. In addition to the fact that these children live under a military occupation that limits their freedom of movement to heath facilities and restricts work opportunities for their parents.



The school currently takes care of fifty one students, between the ages of six and eighteen years old. At  School of Joy students receive vocational  training and olive wood carving skills; one of the most important crafts in Bethlehem, in an effort to help them become active in the working world hence having higher opportunities of autonomy. These children and their families make enormous efforts to attend school, students come from all across the greater Bethlehem area and its surrounding villages in Palestine. They come from poor backgrounds and their families often lack the needed awareness to help them integrate as active members of society. It receives both boys and girls, however considering the conservative culture and lack of awareness within certain parts of the community, girls with special needs are sometimes considered more of a shame that the family tends to hide, rather than seek help. 

 A little bit of help goes a long way! We want to give these brave children the  tools to go through their challenges with more confidence!


Once we reach our goal (with your help!!!) we will keep the campaign open so you can still donate, the extra money raised will be used to renovate the outdoor yard  of the school, for the children to play outside considering  that Palestine has  very few safe playgrounds  for children to play in. 

Who are we?

The Bethlehem 2000 Foundation is a Chilean nonprofit NGO committed to provide Palestinian children with education, health and recreational spaces.  So far we have provided more that 4,800 scholarships, sent 12 medical missions from diverse specialties and have contributed in building 9 recreational parks.  Throughout our work and presence on the field in Palestine, we have witnessed the additional help this school needs! While they manage with local contributions and funding, they struggle with reaching individuals and international societies that will help them develop. The foundation has a team working  both in Palestine and Chile to help follow up on the execution of the project

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can can't make a financial contribution there are other ways that you can of service.  Help spread the word! share our campaign on Facebook, tweet about us, or e-mail  your friends and family.  You can use the indiegogo share tools!
story_txt:
¡La escuela para niños
con necesidades educativas especiales ha estado al servicio de la comunidad
durante 20 años, y hoy necesita nuestro apoyo! 
           
                     
   (To read in English please see below)
School of
Joy es una escuela para niños con discapacidad física e
intelectual, ubicada en Belén, Palestina. Fundada por la Sra. Randa
Abu Saada quién donó una casa para el establecimiento y estableció la
escuela inicialmente con 5 profesores y que hoy cuenta con 11
profesores permanentes y estudiantes voluntarios de las universidades locales
que apoyan el trabajo. ¿Por qué necesitamos
tu ayuda?
School of Joy funciona en la casa de tres pisos donde se
instaló originalmente hace 20 años. En estos momentos aspiramos a renovar su
infraestructura con el fin de recibir más estudiantes y ofrecer espacios
adecuados para los estudiantes con discapacidades físicas e intelectuales. La
escuela tiene tres salas en desuso en el primer piso. Salas que si son
reparadas pueden evitarle a los niños el doloroso proceso de subir uno o dos
pisos por las escaleras para asistir a clases. Los espacios existen pero
requieren arduo trabajo para que puedan ser nuevamente utilizados.Los resultados del proyecto 
Acceso
     directo de los niños a las salas de clasesdesde
     la entrada del colegio, sin tener que subir las escaleras
     diariamente.  
Aumentar
     el número de estudiantes de la escuela, disminuyendo su lista de
     espera. 
Comenzar
     un programa pre-escolar para niños más pequeños, una sentida demanda de
     las familias. 
Conoce a Ibrahim
    



¿Qué hace importante a esta escuela?

 El corazón de este proyecto escolar es ofrecer
educación y un ambiente seguro para niños en situación de discapacidad física e
intelectual en un contexto donde prima la falta de acceso y mucho
desconocimiento de parte de la población en torno a la discapacidad. Estas
dificultades se suman a otras limitaciones que sufren los niños palestinos
producto de la ocupación militar, tales como restricciones en desplazamiento a
centros de salud y falta de oportunidades laborales para sus padres.  
School of Joy es un foco que permite entregar herramientas a los niños y
orientar a sus familias para lograr mayor inclusión. 

Conoce a Firas






La
escuela actualmente acoge a 50 estudiantes entre las edades de 6 y 18 años. Los
estudiantes además de  educación formal reciben orientación vocacional y
se les enseñan técnicas de tallado en madera de olivo, uno de los oficios más
importantes en Belén, esto con el fin de facilitarles el ingreso al mundo
laboral y por ende alcanzar mayores niveles de autonomía. Estos niños y sus
familias hacen enormes esfuerzos para asistir al colegio, ya que provienen de
diferentes localidades de la provincia de Belén y otros pueblos cercanos en
Palestina. La mayoría de las familias carecen de recursos económicos y muchas
veces no cuentan con conocimientos suficiente para apoyar la integración de sus
hijos como miembros activos de la sociedad. 



¡Tú puedes apoyar este proyecto inclusivo!




¿Quiénes somos?
La Fundación Belén
2000 es una organización sin fines de lucro radicada en Chile que busca mejorar
la calidad de vida de los niños en Palestina, a través de ayuda solidaria. Los
fondos obtenidos nos permiten contribuir en forma permanente en tres ejes:
educación, salud y recreación. Hasta la fecha hemos entregado más de 4.800
becas, enviado 12 misiones médicas de diversas especialidades médicas hemos
aportado a la construcción de 9 parques recreacionales con ayuda de
la Fundación. 


A través de nuestra presencia y el
trabajo que realizamos en Palestina hemos podido evidenciar las necesidades de
la escuela! Si bien ellos reciben donaciones a nivel local y algunos
ingresos propios, estos no son suficientes y deben recurrir permanentemente a
benefactores y organizaciones internacionales para desarrollar su proyecto
escolar. La fundación quiere contribuir a su desarrollo permanente a través de
esta campaña y con un equipo de trabajo tanto en Chile como en Palestina, que
apoyará  la ejecución en terreno del proyecto.







Cuando alcancemos la meta propuesta (gracias a tu ayuda!!!) la campaña continuará abierta para quienes quieran seguir donando. Todo el dinero extra recaudado será destinado para restaurar el patio del colegio para que los niños puedan jugar en un espacio seguro, considerando la escasez de espacios seguros al aire libre en Palestina. 
Otras formas de ayudar
Si no puedes hacer una contribución monetaria existen otras formas de colaborar, ¡ayúdanos a difundir esta campaña!, compártenos en Facebook, twitea sobre nosotros, escribe un correo a tus familiares y amigos. Puedes usar las herramientas disponibles de Indiegogo.  Gracias! 
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This school for children with disabilities has been serving its   community for the past twenty years, and is now in need of our support!
School of Joy is a
small town school in the Bethlehem area that offers education and a safe
environment for poor children with physical and intellectual disabilities.
Founded by Mrs. Randa Abu Saada, who donated a house and recruited a staff of
five teachers. Now it has eleven teachers and several 

Why do we need your help?
School  of Joy still remains in the three level house originally donated over 20 years ago. It aspires to restore the infrastructure to be able to receive more children, and offer adequate facilities for their current physically and mentally challenged students. 
The school has three abandoned rooms on the ground floor. Rooms that can save the children from the pain to climb one or two floors  using stairs to go to class. The rooms already exist, but are in need a extensive of work to make them active and useful facilities.  

The results of the project 

Allow  first floor access to a facility
     directly connected to the entrance and            the outside yard. Without having to climb
     stairs daily.
Increase the capacity to receive more
     children to the school hence decreasing the number of students on the
     waiting list.
Start a small kindergarten for children with
     special needs. The school already received many requests from families but
     unfortunately does not have the capacity to admit them.








Why is this school
important?
 The heart of School
of Joy is to provide children a space where integration and acceptance is
possible taking into consideration that still there is lack of awareness about
their needs and abilities. In addition to the fact that these children
live under a military occupation that limits their freedom of movement to heath
facilities and restricts work opportunities for their parents.






The school currently takes
care of fifty one students, between the ages of six and eighteen years
old. At  School of Joy students receive vocational
 training and olive wood carving skills; one of the most important
crafts in Bethlehem, in an effort to help them become active in the working
world hence having higher opportunities of autonomy. These children
and their families make enormous efforts to attend school, students come from
all across the greater Bethlehem area and its surrounding villages in
Palestine. They come from poor backgrounds and their families often lack
the needed awareness to help them integrate as active members of society. It
receives both boys and girls, however considering the conservative culture and
lack of awareness within certain parts of the community, girls with special
needs are sometimes considered more of a shame that the family tends to hide,
rather than seek help. 
 A little bit of help goes a long way! We want to give these brave children the  tools to go through their challenges with more confidence!



Once we reach our goal (with your help!!!) we will keep the campaign open so you can still donate, the extra money raised will be used to renovate the outdoor yard  of the school, for the children to play outside considering  that Palestine has  very few safe playgrounds  for children to play in. 
Who are we?

The Bethlehem 2000
Foundation is a Chilean nonprofit NGO committed to provide Palestinian children
with education, health and recreational spaces. 
So far we have provided more that 4,800 scholarships, sent 12 medical missions
from diverse specialties and have contributed in building 9 recreational
parks.  Throughout our work and presence
on the field in Palestine, we have witnessed the additional help this school
needs! While they manage with local contributions and funding, they struggle
with reaching individuals and international societies that will help them
develop. The foundation has a team working 
both in Palestine and Chile to help follow up on the execution of the
project



Other Ways You Can Help

If you can can't make a financial contribution there are other ways that you can of service.  Help spread the word! share our campaign on Facebook, tweet about us, or e-mail  your friends and family.  You can use the indiegogo share tools!

story:
Who we are:  Ayeish!  A startup nonprofit working to equip political leaders with tools to transform conflict into solution and connection.  We're building collaborations to bring our multiday workshop series to political leaders at various levels and locations.  We're a nonpartisan 501c3.  

About Ayeish
After contemplating entering politics, Ayeish founder Leah Wolfthal realized she could magnify her impact if she could bring tools to other elected officials that would support them successfully mediating the positions they held so deeply, across the political spectrum. After participating in a range of mediation and conflict transformation classes and workshops, she approached Ike Lasater and John Kinyon, co-developers of unique empathy-based conflict resolution techniques, about bringing their curriculum to political leaders. Ayeish is doing just that. The name Ayeish combines the Hebrew word for “fire” and the Arabic verb “to live,” connecting us to our passion of transformative leadership in the service of others. We are a 501c3.  Find us at www.ayeish.org

Trainers

Our trainers have been teaching and refining our curriculum for over a decade, helping individuals, organizations, and families around the world improve their relationships in the midst of conflict. Our primary curriculum developers, Ike Lasater and John Kinyon, are coaches, mediators, trainers, and authors. Their collaboration began with a highly-charged -- and highly meaningful -- mediation skill-building workshop with Afghan elders in refugee camps in Pakistan post-9/11.

Solution Model, Core Skills

Our core conflict transformation process consists of three basic steps that repeat until solutions are reached:

  1. Clarify parties’ underlying needs and desires, as separate from the strategies they say or believe they want
  2. Facilitate parties hearing each other’s deep needs, and foster connection in that understanding
  3. Help parties identify solutions that will meet all of those underlying needs

Our workshops offer a set of supporting skills, including two key skills:

  1. Self-Connection Practice, to have a moment-to-moment awareness of one’s own reactions and needs during an interaction, in order to simultaneously represent one’s own positions effectively and stay centered to facilitate solutions and connection
  2. A four-component Empathy practice that cultivates real understanding between all parties

Methods

Our current model is a sequence of workshops between which participants practice to build habits, supported by coaching. Workshops including the following for each skill or process offered:

  • Conceptual explanation and role-play demonstration at the front of the room
  • Participants role-play practice in pairs and triads using real situations from their lives
  • Group reflection session to share insights and ask questions
