story:
Alexander's Story

                                  

My beautiful boy was diagnosed with autism at age 2 ½ .
Often appearing as if he’s not quite ‘of this world’, you’ll find him in the garden picking flowers and playing with dirt. His face is always covered with remnants of Nutella – firmly encrusted onto his cheeks with little grains of sand.

So happy in his leafy space, it's easy to forget that he has developmental delays – minimal communication, a lack of social skills and dyspraxia. As his mommy, I worry about his future and need to help him understand people and the world around him so that he can protect himself.

In going through the big learning curve of trying to understand and help my son, I have met the most wonderful people – parents, teachers, therapists – all of whom have helped me solve a little piece of our own autism puzzle.

My earlier career in IT inspired me to use my knowledge and expertise to start a business that would:

  • Help children understand social norms through technology.
  • Create a hugely successful business that would one day be able to employ my son in whatever capacity he is able.
  • Create a space where I could hire adults with autism - all of whom would bring their own unique set of skills.

This is how Strange Duck came about…

                                   

Along this bumpy ride – I have learnt many things, including:

  • Alexander has responded positively to children's apps and finds them far easier to relate to than real-life situations. Therefore apps are a great starting point for teaching abstract concepts to children.

  • My hope is to teach our children how to engage and react to social situations - through repetitive learning and in their own time.
    If there is no pressure on them to perform initially, they will hopefully be more open to learning. The app is not a substitute for the real world, merely a starting point - i.e. role playing in preparation for the real thing.

The Plan:

Up until now, I have funded the app project myself. However, as with all things tech- related, things like development and animation can be rather costly!

The app I refer to is actually a series of apps with different scenes mimicking real life eg. a playground, the shops and a children's birthday party etc.

I have already started with the 'playground' scene, but would also like have to another scene, specifically a 'children's birthday party' when I launch the app so that parents and educators have at least two scenes to start working with.

The 'Playground Scene':

Features of the app:

  • The child playing the app - the 'user' - will be encouraged to choose a friend.
  • Once the user has chosen a friend and a piece of equipment to play on, an animation of the two characters on the equipment will be played. This is fun to watch and further reinforces the joy of playing with a friend.
  • A bonus animation will play once the user and friend have played together to further reinforce the idea.
  • Rules - simple visual representations in the form of icons that show you what not to do on the equipment.

                

What I'd like the child to learn:
  • Playing with a friend can be fun!
  • There is structure and order to playing with a friend, it's a skill that can be learned with practice.
  • Play equipment has rules which means that play is not the complete chaos a child with autism may perceive it to be.




The 'Children's Party Scene':

In this 'episode' of the series, my vision is to have the user be one of the characters attending a children's birthday party. He/she will learn about the social norms associated with such an event.

What I'd like the child to learn:

  • What is expected of them when attending a birthday party, like handing over the gift and singing happy birthday while cutting the cake.

  • In this scene, I thought I would use the opportunity to let the user express how he/she is feeling as there is a lot of sensory stimuli at a gathering like this.
    Some children with autism might find it overwhelming from a sensory perspective.
    Icons depicting the various sensory issues will be displayed  - 'too loud', 'feeling shy', 'too many people' etc.
    I want to show the child that it's okay to feel overwhelmed - and that people will help them deal with it. 
  • There will be a group activity - hitting the pinata - which the app will help the user to play with the other children.

Where we are:

  • 100% of graphic design for the playground scene is complete.
  • Some of the sound (voice, effects and music) has been recorded for the playground scene.

            Voice, music and sound recorded by African Treehouse.

                                       
                                        www.africantreehouse.com


  • Approximately 10% of the animation for the playground scene is complete.
  • 0% of the code for the playground scene is complete.
  • The party scene is still in the design phase and needs full funding.
Where we need to be:
  • Finish sound, code and bonus animations for the playground scene.
  • Create the next 'scene' - a children's party. This will require additional graphic design, animations, voice recordings and code.
  • Launch Playground and Children's Party Scene in one app in Google Play Store and Apple App Store.
After investigating market-related prices and getting several quotes, I have learnt that it will cost $40,000 to complete and launch both app scenes, namely the playground and children's party scene.

Money, money, money!

Because my business, Strange Duck, also makes autism aids (flashcards and t-shirts) - I will use the money raised in this campaign to manufacture t-shirts and flashcards for my online store.
Check out my website: www.strangeduck.co.za

Creative Services Expenses:
  • Pre-Production: $5,300
  • Production: $16,000
  • App development: $11,000
  • Sound: $1,000
Other:
  • Perks & Fees: $2,700
  • PR & Marketing: $2,000
  • Roll-out to non-profits & disadvantaged schools: Strange Duck has promised several non-profit organisations here in South Africa a free download of the app. To do this, I'll need some extra funding to buy tablets for the children at these schools as well do training on how to effectively use the app: $2,000

                           

                           Autism South Africa     Ernie Els Centre SA

If funds raised > $32 000 < $40 000:
I will finish the development of the app with the playground scene.
Whatever is left I will then put towards the children's party scene in terms of animation, graphic design, code etc.
If I'm just under target, I will do my best to finish the children's party scene by cutting down on animation etc.
However, if I'm significantly under target, I will finish the development of the app with only the playground scene and sell to local therapists and perhaps have a download on my website only.
It will not be viable to launch in Google Play Store and Apple app store with just one scene.

If funds raised > $17 000 < $32 000:
I will finish the development of the app with the playground scene. It still won't be 100% complete however, so I'll postpone the completion of the project until I can raise the necessary funds.

If funds raised < $17 000:
I will use these funds to manufacture t-shirts and flashcards for my online store. 

Our Impact:

I truly believe in Strange Duck and feel that this is my mission in life.

I want to create real opportunities for my little boy and others through a successful business that not only creates tools that help those with and affected by autism, but also creates a work environment that fosters creativity and embraces neurodiversity.

Risks & Challenges:

Since my team is already in place, I'm not at all concerned with the completion or quality of the project.
My only concern is that because the app is aimed at a niche market, the project may not break even and will run at a loss, as the amount of money needed to create the app is fairly substantial. This will unfortunately mean I won't be able to create more apps, which is the ultimate goal.

To counteract this, I plan to:

  • Enroll the help of a PR person who can help promote the app through social media and other relevant channels.
  • Do my due diligence in pricing the app correctly.

Other Ways To Help

Not everyone can contribute financially. No worries! 

Please promote my campaign through social media and Indiegogo share tools ;)

Thank you!
Karen

story:
Who is the IAGC?

The Intercollegiate Adventist Gay-Straight Alliance Coalition* is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization committed to creating safe spaces on Seventh-day Adventist** college and university campuses for our LGBT+ students.*** You can read more about our 2016-2017 IAGC leadership on our Officer Bios page. 

* IAGC; ** SDA; *** Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and more

Why does this matter?

To be frank, many of us would not be here today if it were not for the support groups currently at our campuses. They became our families and gave us the space to be ourselves without fear. However, too few LGBT+ students walking onto our campuses today know about these unofficial support communities. Research demonstrates that as LGBT+ youth, we are already at higher risk for suicide than other groups, especially since we come from a Christian environment (Bagley & Trembly, 2000; Yarhouse & Tan, 2005). 

Therefore, the IAGC seeks to accomplish the following:

  • Raise awareness for LGBT+ youth and the issues we face on our campuses
  • Initiate dialogue among administration, faculty, students, and the wider community about how we can create safe and loving spaces on our campuses. We need the opportunity to come together as a church family to openly and lovingly discuss the complex intersections of faith, gender, and sexuality.

Which campuses are involved?

Currently, the IAGC works on SDA college and university campuses across North America. At the moment, the following campuses have unofficial student groups:

  • AULL4One - Andrews University
  • Beacon - Union College
  • GASP - Pacific Union College
  • PRISM - La Sierra University
  • SHIELD - Southern Adventist University
  • Will and Grace Collegiate - Burman University
  • ...with more campuses forming groups

What will IAGC do with these funds?

Our minimum goal* is to raise $5,000. Here's what we want to do with it: 

  • Rent out screening sites at five or more Adventist campuses. Fund the transportation costs for either the film/play producers or an IAGC representative to personally attend and moderate the screenings and discussions.
    • Since films and plays about personal stories are beautiful ways to open space for productive dialogue, we plan to host screenings of Enough Room at the Table, A Gay SDA Play, or Seventh-Gay Adventists on/near our campuses starting January 2017.
  • Produce informational materials (posters, brochures, videos of students sharing stories, etc) to spread the word about our campus support groups.
    • As none of our GSAs are allowed to be official campus organizations (as of yet), we critically need creative advertising in order for LGBT+ students to find out about these support systems.
  • Create emergency funds for GSAs across our campuses for students facing urgent needs created by their LGBT+ identity and surrounding environment. 
    • Several times we have had to find housing and give financial assistance to LGBT+ students if their families cut them off. Therefore, we are raising funds to bolster the IAGC and the various support groups' ability to comprehensively address our students' needs (like homelessness or lack of financial help).
  • Create scholarships to fund our IAGC and support group leaders in attending transformative conferences and workshops (such as The Gay Christian Network, The Reformation Project, and Camp Pride) where they can develop skills on how to support LGBT+ students.
  • Assist with the annual organizational fees of the IAGC (such as website fees and advertising costs).
  • Help with expenses incurred in hosting the annual IAGC Summit in 2017, a gathering of all the IAGC officers and current/future student group leaders. 

Every dollar counts. Any and all personal contributions help. Feel free to email us at information@iagcadventist.com you have any questions or comments. 

*As an official 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, flexible-funding (where funds are retained whether the campaign goal is met or not) is the only option given by Indiegogo. As a nationally registered 501(c)(3) nonprofit, the IAGC guarantees that all donations received will be solely used for the items listed above, and full disclosure will be given to any individual inquiring concerning how funds are used. The IAGC will also send tax-deductible receipts to its donors.

Funds are sent by Indiegogo in the form of a check deposit into the IAGC business account, which is supervised by and reported on by the SDA Kinship liaison to the IAGC. As an international nonprofit organization that has been supporting LGBT+ Adventists for decades, SDA Kinship will help oversee this process. The IAGC will then send the money to our various campus support groups, so they can host the screenings/discussions and perform the other activities listed above.

What are other ways I can help?

Even if you are unable to contribute financially, there are other ways in which you can help further support our LGBT+ students:

  • Ask your family and friends if they know of any LGBT+ students and if they have heard of the IAGC and the campus support groups.
  • Share this campaign with family and friends (please use the Indiegogo SHARE tools).
  • STANDout for love and compassion in your churches, schools, and communities. Participate in our #STANDout Day (information included below). 
  • Visit our website to find more ways you can help.

#STANDout Day - Thurs, October 27

You can also show your support for our LGBT+ students by participating in our #STANDout Day. This OCTOBER 27th, we invite you to STAND out for empathy and love by wearing purple or multicolored (rainbow) clothing in solidarity with the LGBT+ students at our SDA campuses. Post a picture to social media with the hashtag #STANDout.
 
Our LGBT+ students across every campus need to know that we will STANDout to support and love them.

Who is the IAGC?The Intercollegiate Adventist Gay-Straight Alliance Coalition* is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization committed to creating safe spaces on Seventh-day Adventist** college and university campuses for our LGBT+ students.*** You can read more about our 2016-2017 IAGC leadership on our Officer Bios page. * IAGC; ** SDA; *** Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and moreWhy does this matter?To be frank, many of us would not be here today if it were not for the support groups currently at our campuses. They became our families and gave us the space to be ourselves without fear. However, too few LGBT+ students walking onto our campuses today know about these unofficial support communities. Research demonstrates that as LGBT+ youth, we are already at higher risk for suicide than other groups, especially since we come from a Christian environment (Bagley & Trembly, 2000; Yarhouse & Tan, 2005). Therefore, the IAGC seeks to accomplish the following:
Raise awareness for LGBT+ youth and the issues we face on our campuses
Initiate dialogue among administration, faculty, students, and the wider community about how we can create safe and loving spaces on our campuses. We need the opportunity to come together as a church family to openly and lovingly discuss the complex intersections of faith, gender, and sexuality.
Which campuses are involved?Currently, the IAGC works on SDA college and university campuses across North America. At the moment, the following campuses have unofficial student groups:

AULL4One - Andrews University


Beacon - Union College

As a nationally registered 501(c)(3) nonprofit, the IAGC guarantees that all donations received will be solely used for the items listed above, and full disclosure will be given to any individual inquiring concerning how funds are used. The IAGC will also send tax-deductible receipts to its donors.Funds are sent by Indiegogo in the form of a check deposit into the IAGC business account, which is supervised by and reported on by the SDA Kinship liaison to the IAGC. story:
Scroll down for English version

La Asociación para la Integración y Progreso de las Culturas (AIPC Pandora), es una organización sin ánimo de lucro que trabaja en educación no formal a nivel internacional, gestionando Experiencias Globales de Aprendizaje con fines educativos, interculturales, solidarios o de inserción profesional en alguno de los 49 países en los que estamos presentes.

ESCUELA DE KALASSA EN MALÍ

AIPC Pandora trabaja en Mali desde el año 2009 y, concretamente, en Kalassa desde el 2011, cuando  un grupo de 10  voluntarios nuestros, se comprometieron con nuestra social local, la asociación “Sourires des Femmes”, a construir una escuela en la aldea de Kalassa, dónde una población de más de 10.000 personas no tenía dónde educar a sus niños y niñas.

Las dos primeras fases de la construcción y financiación de la Escuela

 A su regreso, el grupo de voluntarios se constituyó en comisión de participación y empezó una campaña de recaudación de fondos para la construcción de la escuela. Complementariamente desde AIPC Pandora obtuvimos financiación de las empresas JC DECAUX y BNP PARIBAS, además de muchos donantes privados. En menos de 6 meses, en febrero 2012, se pudo comenzar la construcción de la primera fase de la escuela primaria con dos aulas, baños y despacho para el director, lo que permitió que 112 niños y niñas pudieran empezar a estudiar en los cuatro cursos de primaria en turnos de mañana y tarde.

Gracias a las aportaciones de los ayuntamientos de Torrelodones (Madrid) y Castellbisbal (Barcelona), se puso en marcha, en el 2013,  la segunda fase con la construcción de dos nuevas aulas, además se financió este año escolar. Con esta fase, otros 120 niños comenzaron la escuela secundaria. Además, con el apoyo de una segunda comisión de voluntarios, se constituyó un grupo de costura, dónde se formó un grupo de mujeres que a día de hoy cosen todos los uniformes de los niños y niñas del colegio.

Resultados

Desde el mes de septiembre pasado, 230 niños y niñas están estudiando en la escuela de Kalassa y como es de suponer la escuela ha representado un inmenso progreso para este pueblo.

Tercera fase de la Escuela

Para completar todo el proyecto educativo todavía faltan dos aulas para completar el ciclo de primaria, y la biblioteca, esta campaña de recaudación de fondos se destina a recaudar para estas dos construcciones.

En cuanto a la sostenibilidad, el gobierno maliense comienza a hacerse cargo de los gastos de profesorado una vez se demuestren tres años de funcionamiento y este año, en septiembre, cumpliremos estos tres años así que la continuidad de la Escuela está asegurada, pero hay que completarla con los dos cursos de primaria que faltan.  

Mediante esta campaña, os pedimos apoyo económico para terminar este fantástico proyecto que está cambiando el futuro de toda una generación en Kalassa; ¡dar acceso a la educación supone el don más grande que se puede hacer a una persona en nuestro mundo! Os damos las gracias de antemano por vuestra colaboración y por hacer posible que este proyecto siga creciendo.

¡Muchas gracias!

AIPC PANDORA

The Association for the Integration and Progress of Cultures (AIPC Pandora) is a non profit organization that works internationally in non formal education, organizing Global and Educational Experiences aiming at solidarity, international or professional training, in 49 countries where we are present.  

THE KALASSA SCHOOL, MALI

AIPC Pandora has been working in Mali since 2009, concretely in Kalassa since 2011, when 10 of our volunteeers commited themselves with our local partner, the Assocation  “Sourires des Femmes” (Smiles of Women), to build a school in their town, Kalassa, where a population of more than 10.000 people had no school to educate their children. 

The first two phases of the construction of the school

When the volunteers came back from Mali, they organized a Commission of Participation and developed a fundraising campaign to build the school. In addition, AIPC Pandora received grants from the companies JC DECAUX and BNP PARIBAS, as well as from many individual donors. In less than 6 months, the construction of the first phase of the primary school started: two classes, bathrooms and an office for the director, which allowed that 112 children, from the first 4 years of primary school, began to study in 2012.

Thanks to the contributions of the local governments of Torrelodones (Madrid) and Castellbisbal (Barcelona), the second phase started in 2013 with the construction of two more classes, the funding of all the school costs was also secured.  120 children started to study two more years of education. In addition, a second Commission of Participation organized a sewing workshop, a group of women was trained; today they sew all the uniforms for the children of the school.  

Results

As of September 2014, 230 children are studying at the Kalassa school, which represents a huge progress for the village.

Third phase of the school

The school still needs two classes to complete the full cycle of schooling, and a library; this is the reason why we are raising the funds currently and launching this campaign of microdonations.  

The Project, as for its costs, will be definitly sustainable in September 2015 as the Malian government supports the teachers costs of a school once it has been working for three years, as it will be the case for Kalassa school next September. So, the continuity of the current school is assured but we need two more grades to complete the Primary School Cycle.  

We are asking you for your support to complete this fantastic Project which is transforming the future of a whole generation in Kalassa; the opportunity to study is certainly the biggest gift we can give to the children of our world! Any contribution will be very welcome! We thank you very much for your collaboration which will make possible the expansion of the School.

Again, thank you very much!!!


Breve reseña

Los colaboradores financian ideas con las que se sienten apasionados y a la gente en la que confían. Estas son algunas cosas que puedes hacer en esta sección:

  • Preséntate y cuenta tu historia.
  • Describe brevemente tu campaña y explica por qué es importante para ti.
  • Expresa la magnitud de lo que logrará la ayuda de los colaboradores.

Recuerda, sé breve pero personal. Pregúntate: si alguien dejara de leer aquí, ¿estaría listo para colaborar?

Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes

Presenta más detalles:

  • explica cuánto financiamiento necesitas y a dónde va. Sé transparente y específico, la gente necesita confiar en ti para que quiera financiarte.
  • Cuéntale a la gente sobre tus recompensas exclusivas. ¡Haz que se entusiasmen!
  • Describe a dónde van los fondos si no logras la meta total.

El impacto

Explica tu campaña en mayor detalle y cuéntale a la gente la diferencia que hará su contribución:

  • explica por qué tu proyecto es valioso para el colaborador y para el mundo.
  • Describe tu historial de éxito en proyectos como este (si lo tienes).
  • Haz que la gente lo sienta real y genera confianza.

Riesgos y desafíos

Las personas valoran tu transparencia. Sé abierto y destácate al proveer perspectivas sobre los riesgos y obstáculos que puedes enfrentar en el camino hacia lograr tu meta.

  • Comparte lo que hace que te destaques para superar estos obstáculos.
  • Describe tu plan para solucionar estos desafíos.

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

Algunas personas no pueden colaborar, pero eso no significa que no puedan ayudar:

  • pídele a la gente que difunda tu campaña y que genere eco.
  • Recuérdale que use las herramientas para compartir de Indiegogo.

Y eso es todo.

story: I'm currently on a 2008 Macbook Pro which is on its last legs. At the moment, I use it to write for NerdybutFlirty.com, mod for Geek&Sundry's Twitch, record/upload/edit Youtube videos, work on the Borealis Academy of Magic, stream for multiple DnD campaigns, and various other activities like playing with you all! My current laptop can't handle everything I need to do and regularly crashes which is not helpful when uploading content or in the middle of a fight against a bugbear. My goal is to raise enough to get a mid-price gaming PC, which would be much more efficient for what I need to do. The fundraiser goal covers the cost of the laptop and various fees associated with running an indiegogo campaign.

story:
Short Summary

The Friends of Stackpole Bridge is a group of people who believe that the 167 year old stone bridge in Saco, Maine is a rare gem of rural, functional stonework that should be preserved.  We are up against a public works preference for maintenance-free new bridge.  The decision to choose which plan to go with will be made on May 4.     The more funds we have by that date, the more influence we will have , as cost is also a factor in their decision.

What We Need & What You Get

We have nothing to offer donors except the great feeling you will get if we succeed in saving this rare bridge!  As a 501c3, donations are tax deductible.

The Impact

Our 501c3, the Fund for Stackpole Bridge, has raised over $32,000 in donations and pledges so far from local supporters.

Risks & Challenges

We have been working since 2007 to convince local officials.  Some are adamantly against saving the bridge, but we have gained many supporters

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, a letter of support on our Facebook page would be helpful.

story:
Hi, I’m Stavros - I’m the founder of CampusBus - CampusBus is an entrepreneurial activation project we’ve been running in Greece for a while now.


Maria and I are founders of The Cube, Greece’s biggest coworking space and business incubator - we see a lot of awesome people come though our ecosystem, they’re building businesses, taking care of themselves, solving problems for the world, generating jobs, generating income ánd generally being good citizens.


About a year ago, we were asked by some of our sponsors and supporters to extend our works impact beyond Greece’s capital, Athens - So, we decided to rent a bus and take a few good trainers on a journey throughout Greece, going from village to village, from town to town - teaching people about entrepreneurship, about finance, about modern marketing, about new technologies and about good citizenship. We showed case studies of great businesses and how some people used the comparative advantages of their area they lived in to generate businesses. We visited 12 towns and cities over a 5 month period, we impacted over 2000 people and the results were great. These people had very little regarding entrepreneurship being offered in their areas and we did our bit to push them a little along their entrepreneurial journey.


We’d like to do more of this work in the following months and we’re asking you for your support to get it done.


We’re raising money through Indiegogo to fund the next round of our journey - The money you pledge will go toward covering hiring of a bus, travel expenses for our trainers, educational materials and of course, covering the expense of hiring our trainers again.


We believe entrepreneurship can be the single most impactful answer to Greece’s problems right now. We need people to create jobs, to create their way out of this crisis - to do this, we need to help them discover their greatness, their potential and the potential of their geographical areas.


Any amount you can pledge will be put to good use to the benefit of Greek entrepreneurs beyond the main cities - any amount, no matter how small will help us achieve our goal.

If you believe, as we do, that people have the potential to make their own impact, then please join us in our mission and contribute to this campaign. We promise it willbe impactful. 

After you contribute, please share this campaign with your friends and family or with other entrepreneurs who have made their impact. Everything counts.


Help us make more impact in Greece.


Thank you
story_txt: Hi, I’m Stavros - I’m the founder of CampusBus - CampusBus is an entrepreneurial activation project we’ve been running in Greece for a while now. Maria and I are founders of The Cube, Greece’s biggest coworking space and business incubator - we see a lot of awesome people come though our ecosystem, they’re building businesses, taking care of themselves, solving problems for the world, generating jobs, generating income ánd generally being good citizens. About a year ago, we were asked by some of our sponsors and supporters to extend our works impact beyond Greece’s capital, Athens - So, we decided to rent a bus and take a few good trainers on a journey throughout Greece, going from village to village, from town to town - teaching people about entrepreneurship, about finance, about modern marketing, about new technologies and about good citizenship. We showed case studies of great businesses and how some people used the comparative advantages of their area they lived in to generate businesses. We visited 12 towns and cities over a 5 month period, we impacted over 2000 people and the results were great. These people had very little regarding entrepreneurship being offered in their areas and we did our bit to push them a little along their entrepreneurial journey.We’d like to do more of this work in the following months and we’re asking you for your support to get it done.We’re raising money through Indiegogo to fund the next round of our journey - The money you pledge will go toward covering hiring of a bus, travel expenses for our trainers, educational materials and of course, covering the expense of hiring our trainers again.We believe entrepreneurship can be the single most impactful answer to Greece’s problems right now. We need people to create jobs, to create their way out of this crisis - to do this, we need to help them discover their greatness, their potential and the potential of their geographical areas.Any amount you can pledge will be put to good use to the benefit of Greek entrepreneurs beyond the main cities - any amount, no matter how small will help us achieve our goal. If you believe, as we do, that people have the potential to make their own impact, then please join us in our mission and contribute to this campaign. We promise it willbe impactful. After you contribute, please share this campaign with your friends and family or with other entrepreneurs who have made their impact. Everything counts. Help us make more impact in Greece.Thank you

story:
Michael Imhotep founder of The African History Network and host of "The African History Network Show" and "The Michael Imhotep Show" is raising funds to help run The African History Network, broadcast our 2 radio shows, continue doing the research, organize informative events for the community and keep providing thousands of people with information they have come to rely upon, etc.

As a way of saying thank you for your support you will receive "DVD perks" for your various donation amounts. If you have learned valuable information from our shows, websites, lectures, etc. your donations will be greatly appreciated.

At the African History Network we focus on Educating, Empowering and Inspiring people of African descent throughout the Diaspora and around the world. We empower you with information on our shows dealing with history, culture, economic empowerment, entrepreneurship, health, politics, relationships, technology, entertainment, etc.

Every $10, $25, $50 or $100 helps. If you have any questions you can email us at AHNShow@AfricanHistoryNetwork.com. Thanks for your support.

Listen to our daily radio show, "The Michael Imhotep Show" on The Empowerment Radio Network with host Michael Imhotep, Monday-Friday, 10pm-12midnight EST at http://tunein.com/radio/Empowerment-Radio-Netwo... or listen to the show on your smartphone by downloading the "TuneInRadio" App. Once you download the app search for "Empowerment Radio Network".

Also listen to The African History Network Show, in its 5th year on the air, (March 10th was our 5 year Anniversary) Thursdays, 8pm-10pm EST on The Blog Talk Radio Network with host Michael Imhotep as we interview some of our top Scholars at http://www.blogtalkradio.com/theafricanhistoryn... or www.AfricanHistoryNetwork.com by phone, when we are LIVE at (914) 338-1375. Call in with your questions and comments. Archived episodes are available for you to listen and are also archived on www.Itunes.com.

story:
Short summary

I am the Founder of Afryka Connect Foundation, a  registered a not-for-profit organization with a mission to conducting and supporting activities aimed at bridging the cultural, Educational and economic gap between Poland and Africa. Afryka Connect has a vision to create a community hub where culture, entertainment and technology combine in celebration and commemoration of the achievements and experiences of People of African Descent. The African Centre as a Community hub Facility aims to create a new ‘heart’ for Africa and provide the community with a vibrant, connected and attractive precinct integrating community services and social activities. The Centre will also serve as a hub to promote creativity and innovation in African art, culture, business and entrepreneurship in Poland, offer People of African Descent and people interested in Africa a platform for experiencing exciting and engaging events, lectures, discussions and debates of, scholarly, cultural, human rights and business interests, provide venues for networking, socializing and the meeting of other like-minded people and organizations. The centre  will be located within the city of Warsaw.

What we need the money for

Provide a space for the community to gather, socialize and celebrate, and undertake community initiated services such as:

  • Psychological counseling for victims of hate crime, domestic abuse and other discriminatory related issues.
  • Family Center- i.e families in mixed marriages i.e Polish and Africans, educational socially inclusive Sunday school program aligned with the Church.
  • Library with African literary collections
  • After School Programs
  • Capacity Building Community Events
  • cultural center

The impact

We need to raise money to enable us to rent and furnish a precinct for 1 year whilst we secure further funding for a community hub.

We have been running a wide range of programs on racism, discrimination, hate crime, culture, women empowerment, integration initiatives, debates,training and conference. Our biggest challenge has been a convenient space. This centre will therefore be a community hub for People of African Descent and those interested in Africa.

story:
GETTING READY FOR CAMP (2011)

  

I MET THIS TEACHER LAST YEAR WHEN I SPENT TIME WORKING WITH THE TEACHERS AND STUDENTS AT THIS SCHOOL.  SHE IS SUPERB.  PLEASE HELP HER GO TO TEACHERS' COLLEGE TO GET HER TEACHING DEGREE.  SHE NEEDS YOUR SUPPORT.  PLEASE SEND THIS TO YOUR FRIENDS, FAMILY AND COLLEAGUES. 

 

CREATING A SUMMER EMPOWERMENT CAMP OF FUN AND LEARNING (2012)

 

 

SUMMER SELF-EMPOWERMENT CAMP BREAKDOWN
 
WHO AM I?

I am a retired educator living in Ontario, Canada .  I have a Doctorate
in Education from the Ontario Institute for Studies in Education (University of Toronto).  My special areas of expertise are in Curriculum, Teaching and Learning.

I have taught at every level of the education system both in Canada and
in Jamaica.  I  have emerged with one basic philosophy about students and learning and that is, that every child can learn regardless of their economic and social
background, given the proper tools to do so.  

Learning is not reserved for the rich.  Grasping higher level thinking skills is not only for the rich.  It is for everyone, given the opportunity to do so.  But I have also realized that money and parents' financial status can influence a child's academic performance.  However, with your help and the help of the wider community we can make a difference in boosting a child's intellectual capacity.  We can change the trajectory of their lives by engaging them in critical thinking activities.

THINKING OUTSIDE THE BOX


I have challenged myself to defend the poor and the disenfranchised in
poor regions of Jamaica to help them get rid of 'stinking thinking'
(Zig Ziglar) and empower themselves to live more productive lives.
Disenfranchised young people can achieve their dreams by thinking
outside the box handed to them and be a part of the change they want
to see in the world (Mahatma Gandhi).

 ENCOURAGE THEM  TO BE LIFE LONG LEARNERS

 

EMPOWER THESE YOUNG ONES.  PLEASE SELECT A PERK AND DONATE

STUDENTS AT THE LEADERSHIP TRAINING CAMP (2012)

THE TEAM

A team of Servant Leaders have been travelling around the island of Jamaica each summer (on a limited budget).  The team teaches kids strategies to help them address some of the larger issues that face them on a daily basis. 

WHAT IS OUR GOAL?

TEACH YOUNGSTERS HOW TO FISH

Our goal is to equip these children with skills that can empower them
to rise above their circumstances and better their lives.  Most of us
are acquainted with the expression, 'Give a man a fish and you feed
him for a day, teach a man to fish and you feed him for a life
time.'  The origins of this powerful Chinese proverb  has been
attributed to various people but the meaning surpasses even the
author who wrote this famous quote.  

We want to make it real for these young people.  We want to show them that begging, stealing and anything unethical that they may have turned to in the pastwill get them nowhere and can only lead them to a life of despair and regret.

SELF- EMPOWERMENT

 The goal of training young people in these qualities is to empower them
to see that they are worth way beyond what we can physically give them.
We want them to learn to be independent from an early age.  We want
to train them to think outside the box of poverty, social instability
and chaos.  We believe that they can take the skills they have been
taught to change the trajectory of their lives and never looking behind.

LEADERSHIP TRAINING

We want to help them become leaders in their community at various levels,
whether it is at home, school, church or the wider community.
Through the camps that we have been conducting, a major thread that
we have recognized is the deficit in conflict resolution skills among
a vast majority of young people.  We are helping them change that
attitude.  Open your pocket books and help us fight valiantly for
these young ones.  You only go around ONCE.

 WHAT DO WE WANT TO SEE HAPPENING TO THESE KIDS

  • Increased confidence among participants
  • Develop better conflict-resolution skills
  • More ambitious and better awareness about themselves
  • Become change agents themselves

HOW MUCH DO WE NEED AND WHY DO WE NEED THIS MONEY
Our goal for this summer is $10,000

 

PLEASE HELP US REACH OUR GOAL

 

 

WHERE WILL THE FUNDS GO?

  • To buy computers
  • Training manuals  
  • Tables and chairs 
  • Backpacks and school supplies
  • Uniform for back to school
  • Feeding the homeless
  • Exercise equipment
  • Prepare healthy meals
  • Text books

 

WHO ARE WE TRAINING?

We are training youngsters who would not otherwise have this opportunity.  These kids are poor and they rarely get the opportunity to travel outside of their communities.  We want to make summer come alive for them by providing them with an experience that will forever change their lives for the better.


GETTING TO THE  THE IMPACT.....TRAINING THE FUTURE LEADERS

  • Team building initiatives and activities
  • Study of great Jamaican leaders and why they were successful
  • Study of great international leaders and why they were successful
  • Guest speakers from the community
  • A workday in the community
  • The empowered artist
  • Letter writing to city officials
  • Journal writing (teaching critical thinking)
  • Interactive workshops
  • Money management skills
  • Self- improvement project
  • Reading program (DEAR-DROP EVERYTHING AND READ)
  • Internet connection
 OUR GOAL IS NOT UNREACHABLE. 
 
RISKS AND CHALLENGES
 Life comes with a risk.  We are taking a risk by asking you for your money to help train and educate young people to think at a higher level.  Isnt this an excellent way to spend your money?  Be proactive and join the team of people in the world who are trying to make a difference.   
Choose your cause, select a perk from this cmpaign and help change the world.  Give these young people books and tools so they too can make positive contributions to the society.  They cannot do it by themselves.  They need your help.   They are the leaders of tomorrow. We believe in you our sponsors.  We  must take responsibility for every child who is going hungry in this world.  We must take responsibility for every child who feels lost and forgotten.  But we cannot do it all at once.  
Be a part of the critical mass that is trying to change the world by looking out for the poor and disenfranchised.  We endeavour to maintain our focus to make the Camp a successful one but we cannot do it without you.  The journey of a thousand miles begins now. 
SOME QUESTIONS YOU MAY BE ASKING
How much money from the crowd funding goes towards the summer program?
Indiegogo takes our a small percentage as FirstGiving fees.  The rest goes entirely to the project
What payment method is accepted?
We accept major credit cards
Can I donate from outside Canada?
Absolutely.  We accept money from anywhere in the world
I love the work you are doing.  How can I help with this endeavor?
Servant Leaders (in Ministries) welcome your help.  You can email me at carmenhudson@rogers.com and I will show you the many ways in which you can help. 
 
 A LITTLE THANK YOU NOTE

The children you will be helping to empower this summer and the campaign team would like to say thank you for your support. Please refer to the perks for the donations as we express our gratitude.

story:
Getting out in the world.  

Cabot, Vermont can be a great place to grow up. Nestled in Vermont's Green Mountains, it's a veritable paradise of farms, forests and beautiful views. 


It can also be a tough place to get away from. 

Being a geographically isolated and tiny town (pop. about 1000), opportunities come hard for young people in Cabot. Funds are sparse and connections are tricky. This spring, a group of community bike enthusiasts and the school principal launched a challenge - during the final week of school, encourage 12 students to plan and execute a bike trip from the Canadian border to the southern edge of Vermont. Along the way, students would meet Vermont educational proficiencies focusing on local history, physical fitness, leadership and resilience. 

Doesn't take much. 

We've already started building the trip from the ground up. Accessibility is important, so leaders have encouraged students to fix up whatever bike they came with, to find low-cost outdoor clothing options, and to sign up for the trip regardless of their financial situation. While we're trying to hold the costs down as much as possible, we need help with the basics: 

  • A roof over our heads (camping fees). 
  • Energy to keep us going (food and fuel for our support vehicle).
  • Rainy hour fund (emergency bike repairs). 
Every little bit helps, and we're hoping to do the entire trip for a cost of $50/student/day. When you consider food, shelter, emergency repairs and keeping a support vehicle on the road, this is by no means an expensive proposition. 


And pays off incredibly. 

In a world dominated by screen time and technology, there is true power in being able to travel over 200 miles under one's own steam. As healthy opportunities for youth decrease significantly, we're aiming to reverse some troubling national trends by simply pedaling. Obesity, mental health issues, drug use... these are all challenges staring our kids right in the face. The number of Vermonters seeking treatment for opiate addiction, for example, has risen 771% since 2000. A huge reason for this is the simple lack of anything better to do. 

 The positive benefits and sense of accomplishment from simply pedaling across the state cannot be underestimated! Our students are excited about the opportunity, and we're excited about the chance to teach healthy, lifelong habits. 


Start pedaling!

If just one of our leaders' Facebook friends each contributed $8, our campaign would end in seconds.

 Realistically, we have to cast a wider net. Please help us get the word out by tweeting, forwarding, blogging, Facebooking... anything to help defray our costs over a larger number of people. If we all chip in, we can get these kids across the state!

story:
Walk to Stop Executions!

Scioto Peace and Justice, a local chapter of the Fellowship of Reconciliation, is joining with other organizations and individuals to make the 90-mile walk from the prison at Lucasville, Ohio where the State executes death row prisoners to the Statehouse in Columbus, where legislators have the authority to end the death penalty.  During the seven days of the journey, walkers will participate in nightly programs aimed at reaching local communities in dialogue about State killings in Ohio, both judicial and extrajudicial. 

To operate a support vehicle, provide food, water, nightly shelter for the walkers, and do outreach about why Ohio should abolish the death penalty, it is necessary to raise $1,000.  Please help us raise these necessary funds for an extremely good cause and join us for part or all of the walk if you can.

story:
Since 1986, we've been at the forefront of change within our urban community – empowering young people through arts programming that incorporates...

     

We put creative art to work, helping young people develop the personal and professional skills to meaningfully shape their futures for the better.

     

The impact we have

Fewer than 50% of NYC’s public schools offer the required arts programming that can make a real difference for children at risk. Very few families in Upper Manhattan communities are able to provide that programming on their own. Each year, we serve thousands of those young people through art — both in and out of school.

GET INVOLVED

Creative Art Works’ efforts benefit our entire NYC community, addressing poverty, community development, waning arts education, and urban blight in our own back yard.

Every single dollar counts :-)

Thank you!
story_txt:
Since 1986, we've been at the forefront of change within our urban community – empowering young people through arts programming that incorporates...
      

We put creative art to work, helping young people develop the personal and professional skills to meaningfully shape their futures for the better.

      
The impact we haveFewer than 50% of NYC’s public schools offer the required arts programming that can make a real difference for children at risk. Very few families in Upper Manhattan communities are able to provide that programming on their own. Each year, we serve thousands of those young people through art — both in and out of school.
GET INVOLVED
Creative Art Works’ efforts benefit our entire NYC community, addressing poverty, community development, waning arts education, and urban blight in our own back yard.
 Every single dollar counts :-)
Thank you!

story:
Who We Are and What We Do

In the beginning ….

It all started as a small project in the Pousada dos Duendes guesthouse in 2003 where we helped 6 local children with their basic education and homework. Over the next few years it became so popular that it was no longer viable in the guesthouse.  In 2008 we launched our first fundraising campaign to buy and dedicate a house to the project to increase the number of children we could accommodate, and so the Casa Grande Association was set in motion. Since then we have grown beyond expectation with over 300 children having benefited from the project. Through further donations we have been able to renovate the house and make some much needed structural improvements; we built a bathroom for the children and separated the living area from the classroom. The space currently serves about sixty children. We have no fixed financial support and therefore rely solely on donations.

Some geographical context....

Lencois lies in inland North-Eastern Brazil, on the edge of the Chapada Diamantina National Park.  Historically this is a diamond mining area with huge economic booms and slumps which finally came to an abrupt end in the early 1990s with the prohibition of mining.  The formation of the National Park and the ensuing surge of eco-tourism have given the area a new economic industry but the community was,  and still is, unprepared for the drastic changes to the local economy and the opportunities available. 

At Casa Grande we look to reduce this impact by strengthening the education of children and adolescents by promoting awareness and respect for the environment. Training workshops enable new opportunities for employment (and therefore income) to a region affected by unemployment and low level of formal education after the mining period.


Introducing the children....

The aim of Casa Grande is to give local children a place where they can play and learn in a secure environment and to offer them activities and resources to which they would not otherwise have access. The children who attend Casa Grande reside in the Alto da Estrela neighbourhood, an area of low income in which many families depend on government aid.  Many children drop out of school and most barely complete the first grade. The general age range of the children is from 4 to 14, the majority of whom are very behind in their studies due to lack of support and incentive at home; most of them do not have toys or books in their homes. Casa Grande aims to alleviate this deficiency, in the hope that more children remain in school.

Many of the children come from homes that are emotionally unstable and from as young as 6 years old they are left to spend most of their time unsupervised on the streets.  It is not unusual to find an 8-year-old looking after a 2-year-old sibling.  There are high levels of domestic violence, drinking and drug use in the home which breeds very low self-esteem and blocks their notion of what is right and wrong. As a result, it is easy for them to be enticed into drugs and prostitution; there is a lot of unwanted teenage pregnancy and girls as young as 13 become mothers.

Entertaining the children....

At Casa Grande we aim to find activities and workshops that promote general learning, teach new skills and entertain the children.  We look to give children the opportunity to express themselves and be heard through storytelling. We promote politeness, respect for others and general hygiene; every day when they children arrive, they brush their teeth with their own labelled toothbrushes kept in the house. By allowing the children the opportunity to play in a controlled environment, they can enjoy their free time in a constructive way which helps them to grow emotionally and increase self-esteem, whilst teaching them to share and how to interact with other children without fighting. We also help the children with their homework which demonstrates to them the importance of a formal education, encourages them to stay in school and improves their chances of employment in the future. Through the monitoring, guidance and social-family support which we offer, the Casa Grande Association has developed a greater understanding of the needs of children who participate in our activities.

We endeavour to develop activities that promote respect for the artistic and historical values ​​of the social context of the community through music and dance workshops, visits to museums and libraries and capoeira classes. We also teach basic computer skills, offer foreign language classes and exhibit children's films. At Casa Grande, we encourage the children to learn about their neighbourhood, and have just started a project in which we clean the streets of Alto da Estrela. The children then draw the street onto a map of the neighbourhood and vote to choose the name of this street. By cleaning the streets, the children become more conscientious about dropping litter and the environment, which is of paramount importance in a National Park as beautiful (and clean) as the Chapada Diamantina. This also strengthens the community and promotes citizenship, collective work and the care of public property, whilst also endearing the volunteers to the locals.


Our workshops....

Workshops realised since 2008:

·  2008 – 2010  Grupo Capoeira Cordabamba - Capoeira classes

·  2009 –2010   Casa Afranio Peixoto - Visits to museums and exhibitions of children's films

·  2010 –2011   GAL Lencois Environmental Group - Environmental and sustainability workshops

·  2010 –2013    Fora da Trilha Tour Agency – Rock climbing and conservation

·  2010 – 2012  Visiting street performers - Circus workshops

·  2011  CDC-Center Digital Citizenship - Basic computer skills

·  2012   Capoeira Group Quilombo de Angola - Angola Capoeira classes

·  2012  Avante Lencois - Basic computer skills

·  2013  Association Graos and Grio - Basic computer skills

·  2014    African Ballet Group - African dance

·  2014    Garden workshop and Horta Suspension

·  2015  Percuhitts Group and Coletivo Nossas Raizes – Percussion and instrument construction workshop

Introducing the staff....

The daily activities are run by volunteers who are generally foreign university students studying Portuguese. They spend between three and six months living and breathing the project, and most importantly integrating with the local community through capoeira classes and interaction with the children. This promotes tolerance and openness to cultural, racial and linguistic differences and invites a healthier living dialogue between people from different walks of life. In the new economy of international tourism this is essential for the local community.

In 2015, Casa Grande was awarded a government grant that enabled us to contract one full time member of staff to coordinate the Casa Grande and funded a program of very popular workshops.  This coordinator, Rosa, is responsible for the daily life of the Association, the upkeep of the classroom and volunteer accommodation. She also organises events and coordinates the volunteers during their stay. During this year we have seen huge improvements in the day-to-day organisation of Casa Grande and we have realised the extreme importance of a coordinator to the future of the project.

Rosa has been involved in the Casa Grande since its birth; she was one of the founding members of the association and worked as a volunteer before the official formation of the project. Rosa is a qualified teacher from a local family so, as well as having many years of teaching experience, she is well known and respected in Alto da Estrela, which helps to integrate Casa Grande into the community.

Let’s talk about money....

Unfortunately, the funding for coordinator’s salary and the workshops has now come to an end. We hope to use this fundraising campaign to continue to reap the benefits of having a permanent member of staff, to buy essential equipment for our activities and to continue the workshops which are so gratefully accepted by the community.  Despite being the most important cog in the Casa Grande machine and a qualified teacher, Rosa is prepared to continue to work for the minimum wage, which is well below the kind of salary someone with her qualifications would expect to earn on the open market. To put this in context, the minimum wage in Brazil is 880 Reais a month, which is the equivalent to about 150GBP or 220USD.

Donations from the international volunteers pay for the daily maintenance of the Casa Grande, for example the water, electricity and basic material for activities. We seek donations from visitors to the region in addition to funding from private companies and government departments. We also uphold a calendar of events for fundraising, however this is very time consuming and does not guarantee sufficient income to support and sustain the workshops and the coordinator’s salary.

Fundraising Goals

Our overall target is £14,795 to be distributed in the following three stages:

Stage I:

£2,845 will be used for the purchase of necessary classroom and office equipment and electronics

We are in need of new tables and chairs for the classroom, a projector for films and presentations and a printer and filing cabinet for the administration of Casa Grande. We will also purchase 4 laptops so the children can learn computer skills and the older children can do their homework and research within the Casa Grande. In today's world the basic use of computers is  becoming increasingly essential in the work place.

·  4 Tables    @ £35  = £140

·  24 Chairs    @ £5  = £120

·  2 White boards    @ £35  = £70

·  3 Water Filters    @ £15  = £45

·  4 Laptops    @ £300   = £1200

·  1 Camera    @ £120  = £120

·  1 Projector    @ £400  = £400

·  1 Speaker    @ £150  = £150

·  1 Laser Printer    @ £200  = £200

·  1 Filing Cabinet   @ £150   = £150

·  50 Children's Books  @ £5 = £250

£350 will be used for a trampoline

We would like to buy a trampoline, not only for the children of Alto da Estrela, but for all the children of Lencois. Though this might seem frivolous and extravagant, this would provide entertainment for the children and act as a tool for fundraising. Currently, on public holidays, a trampoline is brought into the centre of Lencois and charges 3Reais for 10 minutes. If we could take the trampoline to other areas, we would be able to continue our fundraising regularly in the town when this campaign has finished. A permanent source of fundraising for Casa Grande would be huge for the sustenance and development of the project.

£1,800 will be used for Coordinator’s salary

We cannot stress enough how important a permanent member of staff is to the project. Everything runs more smoothly with Rosa working and we want to be able to pay her at least the minimum wage for all her hard work. She will continue arranging all the activities listed above and organising more fundraising activities. She also offers essential support and guidance to the volunteers whilst helping with house maintenance and planning; this ensures that they can realise their full potential.

·  12 Months   @150   = £1800

£4,800 will be used for workshops (twice weekly)

After their aforementioned success in previous years we aim to continue with the following workshops. These include the introduction of a new street dance workshop with the hope of involving older children.

·  8 months – African Dance                @£120   = £960

·  8 months – Percussion                      @£120   = £960

·  8 months – Street Dance                  @£120   = £960

·  8 months – Toys from Recycling    @£120   = £960 

·  8 months – Basic Computer Skills @£120   = £960 

Stage II:

If we manage to complete our fundraising for Stage I, £5,000 will be used to develop a plot of land next to the Casa Grande which was donated to the project.

This area is overgrown and on a large angle. It is used as a dumping ground for rubbish and a hangout for drug users. The plot will be cleared and a containing wall will be constructed to level the land. We will then build a wall to isolate it from the street and build an outdoor play area for recreational activities, games and sports so that we can extend Casa Grande activities outside of the classroom.

Stage III:  If we manage to surpass our original target all further funds will go towards the following project:

We have long term plans to build a new teaching and presentation area on the Casa Grande plot.

We are looking to extend the Casa Grande teaching areas by building a new area on the plot of land. This will serve for workshops and presentations so that we have room to accommodate more children from the local area and offer more activities. We also want to build a small area to be a crèche for the younger siblings of the children that come to Casa Grande and a new kitchen so that we will be able to serve food to the children who often have nutritional deficiency.  One of the past volunteers has now qualified as an architect and has drawn up plans for this area.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Spreading the word...

We appreciate any donations you may have to offer – there is no minimum value – even a £1 will help! We would be enormously grateful if you could spread the word about Casa Grande to your family and friends. The more people know about the project, the more we will be able to help improve the lives of these children.

We have accounts on Facebook (Casa Grande Association), Twitter (@CasaGrandeLencois) and now Instagram (@CasaGrandeLencois). Please follow us and spread the word about our project. Even by doing this you are helping Casa Grande and the children we work with.

How else can I help?

There is a huge market for second hand hardware in Brazil and we are now receiving any working mobile phones, tablets or laptops, preferably unlocked and with a charger, to sell here as a further fundraising project.  These items are collected in the UK and brought over by arriving volunteers.

If you are interested in becoming a volunteer, we accept long or short term applications all year round.  A basic knowledge of Portuguese is recommended.

Please contact us at projetocasagrande@hotmail.com for more information on any of the above.

story:
The river Rhine is Europe’s second largest waterway stretching 1,000km from the most southern tip of German past Switzerland, France, Belgium and the Netherlands. To date no human has ever successfully rowed it in it’s entirety, which is what the 3 of us will attempt to do.


We are 3 average Joes who came together last year for a fun rowing event to support a charity for children suffering from cancer. From there we decided to set our stakes higher, challenge ourselves and most importantly make a difference to the lives of children in need.

On Wednesday the 1 July we will assemble our 3 seater rowing boat at Konstanz in Southern Germany (Rhine kilometre 0) aiming to row 50km a day over 20 days until we reach the North Sea in Rotterdam (Rhine kilometre 1000).

The though of rowing the equivalent of more then one marathon a day for 20 consecutive days still seems far away and unreal! 

We are not doing this for kicks (at least not only!) but to support ‘Help for cancer suffering children Frankfurt’, a grass root charitable organisation. It was founded by parents and children who’s lives have been touched and forever altered by the disease. www.hfkk.de

The motto is – You pay we row! For every EUR100  donated we will row 1km, meaning we are aiming to raise EUR100,000 (USD113,000) for this cause.

A big number and a big task! We have started preparing in January and have been since training and suffering in the gym and on the river Main an average of 2hrs every day.

We have been lucky in securing sponsors to provide us a rowing boat, sport and communication equipment, outfits, campervans and a team of volunteers to support us along the way.

We hope that you will be kind enough to support us financially using this forum. Every penny we receive from you goes to the cause. The only expenses we will deduct as incurred are petrol and subsistence during the actual event.

Thank you very much for any assistance!

You will be able to follow our journey via our website 1000.aoty.de and a live feed.

story:
Cash Tales Champion: Write Stories, Change the World!

Have you thought about where your passion for storytelling could take you? Pursue your future to write now with Cash Tales Champion!

What is Cash Tales Champions? In a nutshell, it’s an opportunity! It’s an event to showcase your talent to readers everywhere. It’s a chance for anyone to win glory, prizes, money for themselves, money for their teachers, money for their schools, and a career in writing. 

For some, Cash Tales Champion will change lives with a story. For others, Cash Tales Champion will help start the journey to become the influential writer of a generation. For all, Cash Tales Champion will sustain communities around the world by rewarding the teachers and schools that empower and develop our future writers. Who knows, you may help discover the next great novelist, poet, screenwriter, or playwright may through Cash Tales Champions! 

Each month, writers of all ages from all over the word submit their very best story to Cash Tales Champion within their age group. Members will read and vote for the greatest stories. All 2nd and 3rd place winners will receive ultimate bragging rights and a chance to resubmit their stories again. All 1st place winners take home a monetary prize for them, their favorite teacher, and either their current school or school of choice!

Are you someone or do you know someone who would turn down their monetary prize in exchange for an item of their dreams? For all 1st place writers, Cash Tales Champion will happily oblige a different prize request, whether it be chocolate, diamonds, puppies, or Legos!

Cash Tales Champion makes it simple for writers to participate in the monthly competitions by keeping membership prices affordable for all geographic locations. No matter your age, race, background, level of education, or socioeconomic status, Cash Tales Champions is dedicated to offering all writers a chance to show off their stuff!

Do you think you have what it take to tell the best story? Prove it!

We are excited to get our writing competitions up and running, however, we need a little help along the way! Help us reach our goal of $ 5000.00 or more.

 

How Your Donation Will Support Education Around the World 

Your donation to Cash Tales Champion will help change the world by:  


Building the pool of funds that will used to reward 1st place writers. 40% of every dollar from donations between $1.00 and $99.99 will be awarded to the winning writer.  These funds will be used to help writers
    ⦁    Pay and save for school
    ⦁    Publish their works
    ⦁    Pay for professional advancement opportunities
    ⦁    Support themselves and their families doing what they love
    ⦁    Intrigue, pique, and change the minds of readers across nations

Building the pool of funds that will used to reward teachers and schools. 10% of all donations between $1.00 and $99.00 will be awarded to the winning writer’s teacher, and another 10% will be awarded to the winning writer’s school. These funds will improve the overall education in a winning writer’s community by
    ⦁    Improving teacher salaries
    ⦁    Funding school growth, maintenance, and resources

Supporting the continued development of Cash Tales Champion’s website and operations! 50% of all donations between $100.00 and 10,000.00 will go towards the benefactor’s choice age group for one month. The other 50% of all donations between $100.00 and $10,000.00 will be used to support the developing technology and growing company at Cash Tales Champions. Such developments include 
    ⦁    Improved translation software for international communication
    ⦁    An efficient, precise database of readers and writers
    ⦁    Full time employees to operate competitions, members, hardware, and IT support
    ⦁    Concrete analytics which to network new school districts in our geographic locations
    ⦁    An improved user interface
    ⦁    Gold bracelets to be awarded to donors , winning writers, their teachers, and their schools
    ⦁    Future site and business enhancements 

Increasing the flow and exposure of art and creativity! Your contributions will grant publishers, directors, activists, intellectuals, and the like access to new ideas for
    ⦁    Entertainment
    ⦁    Legislation
    ⦁    Philosophy
    ⦁    Research

story:
Objetivo

La publicación del primer libro de la Escuela Memvus: La Práctica del Ritmo - Lectura Musical Intuitiva. Escrito por Vicente Umpiérrez Sánchez, creador del método Memvus y Director de la Escuela Memvus.

Qué encontrarás en el libro?

  • Una forma intuitiva y estimulante de aprender música apoyada sobre cimiento de la escritura musical intuitiva con sólo dos signos 1 y 0, ideado por Vicente Umpiérrez Sánchez y la posterior conversión al sistema de escritura musical convencional.
  • Recomendada para todo aquel interesado en estudiar de forma profunda el Ritmo, uno de los pilares esenciales de la Música.
  • Recomendado para profesores que deseen poner en práctica éste método en sus clases de música, tanto en Colegios como en Academias, obteniendo una respuesta inmediata y entusiasta por parte del alumnado.

Qué beneficios sociales obtenemos?

  • La difusión de una metodología que lleva funcionando más de 20 años con rotundo éxito en numerosas formaciones infantiles y juveniles.
  • La realización de espectáculos de éxito consolidado como Volcánica, Rompiente y Función de Invierno, donde se consigue lo grande con muy poco, partiendo de la escritura musical intuitiva.
  • El compromiso con la cultura y la formación de nuestros jóvenes tanto a nivel sensible como humano.

El impacto del método Memvus

  • La participación en concursos internacionales obteniendo los primeros premios. 
  • La consolidación en Gran Canaria de Proyectos de gran envergadura artística como las Compañías infantiles y juveniles "Témpore", "Arbos" , Ensembles vocales "Nébula", Ensembles de Percusión "Volcandrum" "Kandinské", "Vacaguaré".
  • La oferta cada vez mas amplia y variada de formación musical tanto para niños, jovenes como adultos.

Cómo puedes ayudarnos?

  • Puedes pre-comprar como COLABORADOR tu ejemplar de "La Práctica del Ritmo -  Lectura Musical Intuitiva".
  • Tu empresa puede ser PATROCINADOR, obteniendo 10 ejemplares y la inclusión del logotipo en la contraportada del libro.
  • Puedes ser MECENAS DE LA ESCUELA , aportando la cantidad que desees  a través de nuestra página web www.escuelamemvus.com.
  • Si no estás interesado en pre-comprar también puedes ayudarnos a difundir esta campaña en las redes sociales. Compártelo!

story:
Short Summary

Havilah Rand is an award winning songwriter, educator and entrepreneur. She has a Masters degree in teaching, five full length albums of original songs and has toured the globe as a solo singer songwriter. For the last decade she has worked as an educator in a variety of learning communities from Tibetan monasteries in India, to private alternative schools, to at risk populations in public schools. She has now combined her passions and expertise into one career by developing Young Songwriter Programs which coach kids in expressing themselves creatively through songwriting. During the workshops and camps, kids are exposed to a variety of activities including theater games, journaling, collaging, nature walks and urban explorations in order to collect ideas for lyrics and song topics. As inspiration builds, the songwriting process occurs both collectively and independently while mentors make themselves available as needed. All songs are recorded on a basic, high quality recording unit with kids being involved as much as their interest dictates.  Each participant is given a recording of all of the songs in the form of a CD which they design and decorate cover art for. 

"We are so pleased with the work that Havilah has done with our daughter during their songwriting workshops.  Havilah has a great gift and real talent for helping kids express their creativity through songwriting, singing & music.  I have seen my daughter gain confidence and a new love of music while working with Havilah. When they are making music together the flow is incredible to see.  I highly recommend Havilah's class!" - Parent of Young Songwriter

"My kids, who were initially both reluctant participants, absolutely LOVED the Songwriter Camp. I am so impressed with the creativity you inspired in them, how you showed them that they can take everyday events and turn them into songs, and how songwriting is an organic process." - Parent of Young Songwriters

The response to these programs has been profound with parents and kids alike using words such as "transformative" and "unbelievably fun and creative" to describe their experience. At a time when funding for music and fine arts in schools is at an all-time low, programs such as this are needed to support creativity, innovation, and authentic self-expression. Numerous studies have shown that music benefits the brain and socio-emotional wellness of children in a variety of ways including improving visual and verbal skills, attention span and alleviating anxiety. Young Songwriter Programs provide young people with a safe forum for expressing their feelings musically and artistically. In the process, they are practicing literacy skills, engaging in positive and cooperative social interactions, using innovative and creative strategies to write and record songs and acquiring a greater awareness of music skills, styles and composition. 

What We Need & What You Get

At this point, Young Songwriter Programs are being run by a one woman machine named Havilah with occasional assistance from her wonderful musical friends and supporters. As these programs build momentum, more instruments and recording gear are needed. Time is needed to organize future workshops and camps and to develop an academic enrichment program to bring to public schools. Here is the breakdown of how funding will be allocated. 

  • Pay off $1500 credit line that was used to buy the microphones, computer and  materials we are currently using. 
  • $1500 to purchase a second computer and another microphone so that more than a few kids can be recording their songs at a time. 
  • $1000 for another guitar and other instruments.
  • $1000 to renovate a studio that Havilah owns in Bellingham, WA so that it can be used for private coaching, small group classes and office space. 
  • Any funds raised over our goal of $5000 will be used for travel expenses, scholarship funding and compensation for time spent researching, networking, promoting and planning future Young Songwriter Programs. 
In return for your donation to Young Songwriter Programs we are offering everything from songs written by participants of past workshops and camps, to short videos of our programs in action, to bringing a songwriting workshop to your community. The greatest benefit is that you will be connected to a community that believes children need opportunities like this to explore their passions and talents while navigating feelings of vulnerability and uncertainty within a safe and supportive environment. Most importantly, Young Songwriter Programs give young people an opportunity to play with words, music and technology in order to create something utterly new and exciting.

While we certainly hope to make and possibly even exceed our goal, every bit helps and will be put towards more materials and efforts to expand the Young Songwriter Programs. 

Other Ways You Can Help

While money helps, there are other ways you can support the growth of Young Songwriter programs. Here are a few ideas..

  • Gather 3-5 kiddos and host a young (or adult) songwriters workshop at your home or community center.
  • Share info about the Young Songwriter Programs with parents, schools and home school communities in your town.
  • Spread the word about this fundraising campaign by sharing on social media and through email. 
  • Send positive thoughts and word of encouragement:) 
Thank you in advance for your generosity and positivity!

story:
Our Story

Ombelico Mask Ensemble is raising funds to offer scholarships to students who want to attend Ombelico Mask Academy. The Academy is a new study abroad program for learning Commedia dell'Arte in Italy... the land where it all began.

Our mission has always been to offer our work to as many people as possible. That's why we do a free outdoor show every year, and that's why we are asking for your help now. 

With your help, more students from more walks of life will be able to study this unique theatrical form of cultural heritage.  

The more we raise, the more we can offer to students. This scholarship will help defray the costs of flights, trains, food, and tuition.  

What We Need & What You Get

Ombelico Mask Academy is a joint venture with West Chester University. WCU has already agreed to offer $10,000 in scholarships for this program. We at Ombelico want to match (and maybe exceed!) their offer to help get this program off the ground in its inaugural year. 

With tuition, flights, trains, and food , the total cost to attend the Academy is approximately $6,500 per student.  If we reach our goal of $10,000 we will offer 5 students scholarships of $2,000 each. If we raise more, we can offer more! 

We have some exciting perks too! From surprise thank you emails and long-winded monikers to Ombelico swag and a custom leather mask, we have something for everyone to say, "Thanks for helping students study this cultural treasure and have a transformative life experience!" 

If everyone who reads this gave just $10, we would reach our goal. And, if we don't reach our goal, whatever money we raise will still go towards defraying costs for students!

The Impact

Here at Ombelico,  we strive for more laughter and joy in the world. Commedia dell'Arte happens to be the style we're good at... but at the heart of it all, we just want to make the world a better place. 

We've been making free, accessible, family-friendly, outdoor comic theatre for almost 10 years now. Ombelico Mask Academy is the next level of growth for us. This is a new way to reach more people. And just like our theatrical shows, we want to make this truly unique experience (really. check. there's nothing quite like us out there) available to as many people as possible.  Making it affordable makes that possible. 

Risks & Challenges

Launching a brand new theatre school in a niche style isn't easy. And we're launching it now, for the summer of 2016... which means even if students are interested, they haven't had time to save up for it. 

But if we don't launch this year, it's very unlikely it will happen at all. In order to maintain the relationships we have with WCU, the teaching artists, and our partners in Italy... we have to make this summer work. 

If 15 students sign up, we can run Ombelico Mask Academy. If we can offer an additional $10,000 in scholarships, it's more likely we can find those 15 students. Plain and simple. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We get it. Sometimes you just can't help out financially. That's OK. Heck, we're glad you've read this far in the description! 

So since you've come this far... why not make a few more clicks of the mouse and tell people about this? Share this on Facebook and Twitter and email and all that. Indiegogo has some sharing tools to make it easy.  

Especially if you are connected to a university in some way. If you or your cousin/aunt/son/sister-in-law is attending or working at a university, see if they can spread the word to their theatre department!

Thanks!
